snippet: Jonathan Reynolds article recalls dining alone on apple pancake at former New York City restaurant one Christmas in 1960's when he had fought with his mother; suggests self-indulgence as way to cope with self-pity and sorrow; recipe (M)
lead_paragraph: A great pal of mine at the somewhat curious high school I attended was Ronnie Reuben, one of six grandchildren of Arnold, the feisty German immigrant who founded and maintained Reuben's, which from the late teens till the 60's was the show-biz-journalist-politico-occasional-mobster restaurant of choice. It was open 24 hours a day and was sort of a cross between Katz's Deli, Liquids and Nobu. Among other things, Ronnie introduced me to the most self-indulgent meal I had until I was 33 and ate at a German beer hall in Munich, after which I thought I was literally going to explode. Reuben's also taught me that when the holidays roll around and you're solo, exuberance and self-indulgence can keep the worst of the demons at bay.
abstract: Jonathan Reynolds article recalls dining alone on apple pancake at former New York City restaurant one Christmas in 1960's when he had fought with his mother; suggests self-indulgence as way to cope with self-pity and sorrow; recipe (M)

snippet: Philips family maintains Talavera, estate in Claverack, NY, that has been in family for nearly 200 years, by becoming modern apple growers; Leila Philip, professor of English at Colgate University, tells its story in A Family Place: A Hudson Valle...
lead_paragraph: FROM Route 9H, you can just glimpse Talavera, a yellow, Greek revival mansion with white trim and fluted columns. The house, serenely overlooking the Catskills and the Berkshires, seems deliberately hidden as you wind your way up a long driveway. Only as you reach the foot of the spacious lawn does Talavera reveal itself in all its faded elegance, subject to the inroads of time but occupied in unbroken succession by the Van Ness and Philip families for nearly 200 years.

snippet: Museum of Modern Art's design collection acquires Apple Computer's G4 Cube computer, which has gone out of production because of disappointing sales; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: ''True, it looks like it belongs in the Museum of Modern Art,'' read an advertisement from Apple Computer last year. ''But the G4 Cube is actually a supercomputer that belongs right on your desk.'' Now, less than a year after its introduction, the Cube is indeed in the Museum of Modern Art -- and out of production. The Cube was acquired for the Modern's design collection, along with six other Apple products, shortly before Apple announced the Cube's demise.

snippet: Stephen Wozniak, co-founder of Apple Computer, will join board of directors of Danger Inc, company developing wireless Internet device; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Danger Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up working on an always-connected hand-held Internet device, will announce today that Stephen Wozniak, a co-founder of Apple Computer, will join its board. In an interview, Mr. Wozniak, left, who created Apple with Steven P. Jobs, said he would contribute engineering and entrepreneurial advice. Danger, based in Palo Alto, Calif., expects to begin selling its first device, called the Hiptop, for about $200 early next year through an undisclosed telecommunications carrier. Intended to compete with devices like the Blackberry pager, the Hiptop will enable users to check e-mail, surf the Internet and store appointments and contacts. In October, Danger raised $36 million in financing from venture capital concerns. ''I think they have an interesting ride ahead of them,'' Mr. Wozniak said. Chris Gaither (NYT)
abstract: Stephen Wozniak, co-founder of Apple Computer, will join board of directors of Danger Inc, company developing wireless Internet device; photo (S)

lead_paragraph: BY the usual yardstick of market share, Apple Computer is a computing pipsqueak. Its slender slice of personal computer sales is less than 4 percent in the United States, and its share of the global market is even slimmer. Yet in terms of industry attention, press coverage and attendance at trade shows like the Macworld Expo in New York last week, Apple still looms pretty large.

lead_paragraph: Trying to entice consumers with wild patterns referred to as Blue Dalmatian and Flower Power molded directly into the plastic of the popular iMac home computer, the chief executive of Apple Computer, Steven P. The new multihued iMacs, which will have faster processors and the ability to both read and write CD's, will be priced at $899 and $1,499. snippet: Apple Computer cuts prices up to $1,000 on its desktop and portable computers (S)
lead_paragraph: Apple Computer cut prices up to $1,000 on its desktop and portable computers yesterday. The company made the changes quietly, by posting the lowered prices on its Web sites with no public announcement. A spokeswoman said the company was currently in a quiet period and would have no comment. The company said last month that it was planning to make a series of moves to reduce inventory, and a person close to the company said recently that Apple was hoping to reduce its inventory drastically to put its business problems behind it quickly. The company reduced the price of its entry-level G4 tower computer by $300 to $1,299, while the price of its G4 Cube computer, which has met disappointing demand, was lowered to $1,499 from $1,799. Apple's retailers said it had also reduced prices on portable systems, and its G3 Portable now sells for as little as $2,199. Prices were not lowered in either the iMac desktop or iBook portable systems. Apple is expected to introduce new computers at its annual Macworld event next week in San Francisco and several weeks later in Tokyo. John Markoff
abstract: Apple Computer cuts prices up to $1,000 on its desktop and portable computers (S)

lead_paragraph: With the eyes of a nervous nation fixed upon him, George W. Bush began coming of age as president this weekend.
abstract: With the eyes of a nervous nation fixed upon him, George W. Bush began coming of age as president this weekend.    In the capital and in New York City, in settings both formal and informal, Mr. Bush sought to lift the spirits of the American people in the wake of Tuesday's horrific terrorist attacks. He sought to console the bereaved, comfort the wounded, encourage the heroic, calm the fearful and, by no means incidentally, rally the country for the struggle and sacrifice ahead.

snippet: Gerard Strembridge's teasing romantic comedy is implausible chronicle of a rake (Stuart Townsend) who adopts the saintly guise of an empathetic Mr. Right to work his wiles. What complicates Adam's seductions immeasurably is that three of the women...
lead_paragraph: In a climate of rampant confession, where every talk show oracle encourages brutal, unbridled honesty, the premise behind Gerard Strembridge's teasing romantic comedy ''About Adam'' seems refreshing, even mildly subversive. The implausible chronicle of a rake who adopts the saintly guise of an empathetic Mr. Right to work his wiles, it promotes the sensible notion that a little discretion and secrecy are necessary to maintain domestic peace.
abstract: Gerard Strembridge's teasing romantic comedy is implausible chronicle of a rake (Stuart Townsend) who adopts the saintly guise of an empathetic Mr. Right to work his wiles. What complicates Adam's seductions immeasurably is that three of the women with whom he sleeps (more or less at the same time) are sisters, and the fourth is the girlfriend of their brother. Guilt-free and nearly devoid of erotic angst, "About Adam" is the flip side of movies like "Teorema," "Something for Everyone" and those slogging Tennessee Williams dramas in which an irresistible, omnisexual stud is often an angel of death. Here he is an angel of sexual health in an impossibly euphoric world where sibling rivalry and sexual jealousy are only passing twinges of discomfort, not consuming passions. -- Stephen Holden

snippet: Pres Bush's embrace of religion-based social programs may well strike chord with American belief in second chances; photo; Bush himself points to his own faith-inspired transformation from hard-drinking oilman to viable politician, while Bill Clin...
lead_paragraph: THE stories a people tell and retell reveal a lot about who they are and who they want to be, and there is no public narrative more potent today -- or throughout American history -- than the one about redemption. In recent years, the old religious belief in hard-won salvation, based on prayer and good works, has begun to morph with the therapeutic language and formulas of the recovery movement. The dark night of the soul has increasingly given way to public confessions on Oprah and Sally Jessy Raphael; the arduous process of genuine contrition, to mechanical avowals of regret -- and equally automated dispensations of forgiveness (or forgetfulness).
abstract: Pres Bush's embrace of religion-based social programs may well strike chord with American belief in second chances; photo; Bush himself points to his own faith-inspired transformation from hard-drinking oilman to viable politician, while Bill Clinton has made so many comebacks and performed so many mea culpas that even critics have lost count (M)

snippet: Some Macintosh computer users lose data from their hard drives as result of bug in program that Apple Computer made available for use in installing latest version of Apple's new music software, iTunes 2.0 (S)
lead_paragraph: Some Macintosh computer users lost data from their hard drives as a result of a bug in a program that Apple Computer made available over the weekend, the company said yesterday. The bug was part of a program used to install the latest version of Apple's new music software, iTunes 2.0. Apple made the software available for download on its Web site on Friday night. The company said it quickly heard from several people who said their hard drives had been damaged when they installed the program. Apple said it had identified the problem and replaced the problem program by Saturday morning. The problem had not affected everyone who downloaded the program, Apple said, but only a subset who, among other particulars, were using Apple's Mac OS X operating system and had partitioned their hard disks into two or more drives. Matt Richtel (NYT)
abstract: Some Macintosh computer users lose data from their hard drives as result of bug in program that Apple Computer made available for use in installing latest version of Apple's new music software, iTunes 2.0 (S)

Apple's announcement that it would stop selling computers through Best Buy, Circuit City, Of-ficeMax and Sears was made in February 1998, not recently. Circuit City resumed Apple sales last July; sales also resumed for a time at Sears but have again been discontinued.

snippet: This comedy-drama written by, produced by and starring Jerome Courshon, breaks little new ground in the yuppie reunion genre. In Mr. Courshon's film (he is clearly the auteur, although the direction is by Paul Leaf), five boyhood pals gather at a ...
lead_paragraph: ''God, Sex & Apple Pie,'' a comedy-drama written by, produced by and starring Jerome Courshon, breaks little new ground in the yuppie reunion genre, a formula that dates from the earliest years of American independent filmmaking (''The Return of the Secaucus Seven'') and was definitively Hollywoodized by ''The Big Chill.''
abstract: This comedy-drama written by, produced by and starring Jerome Courshon, breaks little new ground in the yuppie reunion genre. In Mr. Courshon's film (he is clearly the auteur, although the direction is by Paul Leaf), five boyhood pals gather at a cabin in the woods for a Fourth of July weekend. Scrupulously following the dramatic formula, the characters, all in their early 30's, are soon sharing their most intimate secrets, their most bitter disappointments and their most desperate yearnings. When a bartender asks one character, "What can I get you?," he replies, "How about a new life?" A new script would be a better solution for everybody. — Dave Kehr

lead_paragraph: Report Offers Conflicting Signals on the Recession
abstract: Report Offers Conflicting Signals on the Recession  The economy shrank much more this summer than the government initially estimated, the Commerce Department said. The revised report offered conflicting signals about how long the current recession would last.    In the third quarter, the economy contracted at an annual inflation-adjusted rate of 1.1 percent, its worst showing since 1991, during the nation's last recession. The government had originally reported a 0.4 percent decline, but new data led to the steeper drop reported in the scheduled revision. [Page C4.]

lead_paragraph: For a generation of up- and-comers in the money world of Lower Manhattan, the scene was deeply familiar: David Alger's lunch table. Nothing fancy about it -- Mr. Alger seemed to thrive on cheeseburgers and apple pie, and any nondescript Wall Street coffee shop would do. His stories are what live on, and the lessons embedded within them about the stock market, and about life.

snippet: Norm Oshrin reviews Dee's Bagel Cafe/Deli & Grill in Monroe, NJ; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: In October, John Ingram had an idea. Why not make pumpkin-walnut cream cheese for the season? That's what he did -- nothing new for him. It just added to his noted repertory of creative cream cheeses: from olive-pimento to walnut-raisin to strawberry. Mr. Ingram, a former trucker, makes them at Dee's Bagel Cafe/Deli & Grill in Apple Plaza in Monroe. Outside the four-year-old establishment, diners are greeted by a smiling 6-foot-plus-tall wooden caricature of the 5-foot-3-inch former nail technician Denice (Dee) Ingram, John's wife. The wooden Dee is holding a hamburger, surrounded by a muffin, coffee and other goodies. Inside are sculptures of bagels that transmute into, for example, a tossed salad, a Danish, a bowl of soup. The Ingrams, who commute from Burlington Township, about a half-hour away, draw most of their patrons from the handful of adult communities in the township. At lunchtime, the cafe can serve up to 26 diners, many from surrounding businesses like a Sony warehouse, Aetna and Home Depot. There also is delivery for orders of at least $15. Lunch can be anything from salads and club, combo or deli sandwiches and wraps to baskets, burgers and grill -- all $4 to $6. Available any time, is a dish ($4.59) made from eggs, three cheeses, bacon and onions: the ''Deelux'' Cheese Omelette. Norm Oshrin
abstract: Norm Oshrin reviews Dee's Bagel Cafe/Deli & Grill in Monroe, NJ; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: TO do-it-yourself moviemakers, nothing is more frustrating than the current chasm between the technology for creating digital movies and the technology for distributing them. The first part is easy: using a $700 digital camcorder, you can capture footage with astonishing detail, sharpness and color fidelity. Using editing software, you can add credits, fade-ins and fade-outs, and music from an audio CD. The quality of the result is simply spectacular -- when played back on your computer monitor or the camcorder's little flip-out screen.

lead_paragraph: Lehman Maupin
abstract: Lehman Maupin  39 Greene Street, SoHo  Through Nov. 3      ''Because Nothing Has Changed,'' the installation piece that dominates Anya Gallaccio's debut exhibition in New York, lives in the mind like a great stage set. The work centers on a bluntly truncated tree that is unnaturally laden with bright red ceramic apples. But much of the drama comes from the gallery's plywood floor, which has been scorched black; it intensifies the sense of an eerie landscape, at once stark and excessive, in which nature is out of balance.

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Cafe Sabarsky in Neue Galerie museum on Fifth Avenue; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The new Neue Galerie is a pocket-size museum devoted to early modernist German and Austrian art. It aims to fill a niche. And somewhere along the way, someone had the bright idea of letting the art dictate the food, which, in its own way, fills another niche. In a small room to the right of the entrance, Kurt Gutenbrunner, the chef and owner of Wallsé, has created a Viennese cafe, named after the collector Serge Sabarsky, whose works help form the basis of the museum's collection. It is deliberately humble, with homey, robust Austro-Hungarian dishes, a few Austrian wines and lots of Viennese desserts.

lead_paragraph: SKIN-DEEP FISCAL HEALTH Cosmetics Plus, a New York chain of stores specializing in makeup and perfume, has filed for bankruptcy and has asked the court for permission to auction off its business name, leases and other assets. The family-owned company, which once had the specialty beauty market virtually to itself, has faced growing competition in recent years from newcomers like Sephora and Aveda. Industry experts say Cosmetics Plus was distracted by a failed Internet venture and also ran into trouble when it tried to expand to Southern California. Today, Cosmetics Plus has 22 stores in the New York area. The owners, Robin and Toby Bartosh, did not respond to a request for comment. Terry Pristin (NYT) REFUNDS ON CAR LEASES The Banc of America Auto Finance Corporation has agreed to refund overcharges it collected from New Jersey customers for what the company had called excessive wear and damage on leased automobiles, state officials say. To settle a lawsuit brought by the state, the company also agreed to pay the state $350,000 to cover the cost of its investigation and to finance future consumer protection programs, the agency said. The company did not admit any wrongdoing. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

snippet: Chef David Burke introduces line of frozen amuse-bouches called Gourmet Pops; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The amuse-bouches that David Burke came up with for Park Avenue Cafe and One C.P.S., the restaurants where he is chef, were so popular that he is now selling them at retail. Called Gourmet Pops, they include smoked salmon wrapped around a cream cheese filling, creamy herbed goat cheese with a nubbly almond and pistachio coating, and foie gras that's glazed with port and cranberry jelly and looks like a little candy apple. The frozen pops, 12 to a box and a bite or two each, thaw in less than 30 minutes but should be served chilled. The goat cheese is $18, the smoked salmon $20 and the foie gras $22 at Dean & DeLuca and at Kings Super Markets in New Jersey. At Caviarteria, a box of 12 in assorted flavors is $25.

snippet: Stephen Jay Gould Op-Ed column says that at time of tragedy and terrorism we must affirm essential truth that good and kind people outnumber others by thousands to one; tells one tiny story, of delivering warm apple brown bettys sent by local rest...
lead_paragraph: The patterns of human history mix decency and depravity in equal measure. We often assume, therefore, that such a fine balance of results must emerge from societies made of decent and depraved people in equal numbers. But we need to expose and celebrate the fallacy of this conclusion so that, in this moment of crisis, we may reaffirm an essential truth too easily forgotten, and regain some crucial comfort too readily forgone. Good and kind people outnumber all others by thousands to one. The tragedy of human history lies in the enormous potential for destruction in rare acts of evil, not in the high frequency of evil people. Complex systems can only be built step by step, whereas destruction requires but an instant. Thus, in what I like to call the Great Asymmetry, every spectacular incident of evil will be balanced by 10,000 acts of kindness, too often unnoted and invisible as the ''ordinary'' efforts of a vast majority.
abstract: Stephen Jay Gould Op-Ed column says that at time of tragedy and terrorism we must affirm essential truth that good and kind people outnumber others by thousands to one; tells one tiny story, of delivering warm apple brown bettys sent by local restaurant to rescue crews at World Trade Center site (M)

snippet: Neighbor Corp's EIEIO Tomato Smash is blend of tomatos, celery, spices and citrus that can serve as handy base for gazpacho; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The Neighbor Corporation of Wakefield, Mass., claims that EIEIO Tomato Smash may help prevent Type 2 diabetes and lower the risk of cancer, and that it provides 130 percent of the recommended daily allowance of vitamin A. What the earnest company doesn't claim is that the juice can save a last-minute dinner party. With a garnish of cilantro or chopped cucumber, it becomes instant gazpacho. There are tomatoes, of course, and celery. But then there is spice and acid and a pervasive sweetness, from ingredients like apple juice and beets, and a garden full of other produce -- cucumber, watercress, pepper, garlic, lemon and spinach. All are blended in thoughtful proportion, so you can pop open a bottle and taste a dash of summer. A 10-ounce bottle is $1.99 at the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street; 24 ounces is $2.99 at Whole Foods, 250 Seventh Avenue. AMANDA HESSER

snippet: David C Nagel, chief technology officer at AT&T Corp, is named president and chief executive officer of new software subsidiary of Palm Inc; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Palm Inc. has appointed David C. Nagel president and chief executive officer of a new software subsidiary. Mr. Nagel, 56, has served as AT&T's chief technology officer since 1996 and is already a member of the board of Palm, the hand-held computer maker. Before coming to AT&T, he headed research and development at Apple Computer. The move comes soon after Palm bought the software created by Be Incorporated, an innovative operating system company formed by another Apple alumnus, Jean-Louis Gassée. Like many high-tech companies, Palm has suffered a drop in sales this year. In a statement, Mr. Nagel said that he was ''delighted to lead the Palm platform business'' into such new areas as wireless communications and multimedia. John Schwartz (NYT)

snippet: D-Link's new portable hard drive, intended for toting around music, offers 10 gigabytes of memory, enough for over 130 hours of music at standard MP3 quality; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: While it lacks the monochrome sleekness of the smaller Apple iPod, D-Link's new portable hard drive, intended for toting around music, has other notable features. At 10 gigabytes, enough for more than 130 hours of music at standard MP3 quality, the D-Link Roq-it has twice the storage capacity of the iPod player. And unlike the iPod, it works with both Windows (98 and later) and Macintosh (OS 9 and later) machines. Perhaps even more attractive, the Roq-it costs $229, compared with $399 for the iPod.

snippet: "When he came here . . . the whole village made a jest of his youthful looks and laughed at the idea of being preached at by such a pup. If they saw him now, they would not laugh . . ."
lead_paragraph: Iused to love this season. The wood stacked by the door, the tang of its sap still speaking of forest. The hay made, all golden in the low afternoon light. The rumble of the apples tumbling into the cellar bins. Smells and sights and sounds that said this year it would be all right: there'd be food and warmth for the babies by the time the snows came. I used to love to walk in the apple orchard at this time of the year, to feel the soft give underfoot when I trod on a fallen fruit. Thick, sweet scents of rotting apple and wet wood. This year, the hay stooks are few and the woodpile scant, and neither matters much to me.
abstract: "When he came here . . . the whole village made a jest of his youthful looks and laughed at the idea of being preached at by such a pup. If they saw him now, they would not laugh . . ."

snippet: The amuse-bouches that David Burke came up with for Park Avenue Cafe and One C.P.S., the restaurants where he is chef, were so popular that he is now selling them at retail.
lead_paragraph: The amuse-bouches that David Burke came up with for Park Avenue Cafe and One C.P.S., the restaurants where he is chef, were so popular that he is now selling them at retail. Called Gourmet Pops, they include smoked salmon wrapped around a cream cheese filling, creamy herbed goat cheese with a nubbly almond and pistachio coating, and foie gras that's glazed with port and cranberry jelly and looks like a little candy apple. The frozen pops, 12 to a box and a bite or two each, thaw in less than 30 minutes but should be served chilled. The goat cheese is $18, the smoked salmon $20 and the foie gras $22 at Dean & DeLuca and at Kings Super Markets in New Jersey. At Caviarteria, a box of 12 in assorted flavors is $25.

snippet: Neil Strauss reviews album Smashing Pumpkins: Greatest Hits (S)
lead_paragraph: SMASHING PUMPKINS: Greatest Hits'' (Virgin). This is a well-done tribute to the legacy of one of the most important rock bands of the 90's, and at one point the biggest. At 18 tracks, the first disc in this two-CD set, titled ''Rotten Apples,'' initially seems to fall short, missing so many of the band's great songs, but that is not its purpose. It tracks a few standout songs (not always hits) from each CD by a band that always managed to be completely alternative- and mainstream-minded at the same time, never losing its artistic vision in the morass of success pressures and intra-band problems. The collection traces the evolution of Smashing Pumpkins from the intensely textural rock onslaught of its first albums to the pop grandiosity of its glory days to the more conceptual and stylistically far-reaching songs of its final years. For the second disc, I would have liked an official CD of the band's Internet-only album, ''Machina II.'' Instead, there is a disc called ''Judas O,'' which is an impressively high-quality collection of B-sides, tracks from ''Machina II'' and other rarities (a follow-up to a similar collection from 1994, ''Pisces Iscariot''). NEIL STRAUSS
abstract: Neil Strauss reviews album Smashing Pumpkins: Greatest Hits (S)

snippet: Eric Asimov comments on delights of pinot blancs (S)
lead_paragraph: COMPARED with the heartbreaker allure of pinot noir or the vivacious snap of pinot grigio, pinot blanc has an anonymous ring to it. No one would speak of a sassy pinot blanc or a brooding pinot blanc, as he might of a Beaujolais or a Bordeaux. In fact, when speaking of pinot blanc, one may not mean pinot blanc at all: studies have shown that some of the pinot blanc vines in California are actually melon de Bourgogne, the grape of muscadet.

snippet: Karla Cook reviews Soupe du Jour restaurant in Hopewell, NJ; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: SOUPE DU JOUR is no Denny's. It is tucked away off the main street of this little town, with only a vaguely tattered sign to show the way to the parking lot and the low building at the end of it. Inside, it's far out, or something -- the walls decorated with Grateful Dead photographs and the front page from the day Nixon resigned. The peeling ceiling is a sky blue with trompe l'oeil clouds here and there. The 12 tables are a little tight, a little loft holds extra paper towels, a cupboard stores about 30 cookbooks and other supplies. In the teeny tiny bathroom, there are a pair of fish-net-stockinged legs mounted on the wall and crossed suggestively.

snippet: Think Tank column appraises Carolyn Wyman's new book, Jell-O: A Biography; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Giddily artificial and perpetually in motion, Jell-O is arguably more American than apple pie, and certainly more versatile. (Ever try to wrestle in pie?) To most of the world, it may look more like a prank than a food: immigrants at Ellis Island were unnerved when offered a confection that shuddered when touched. But since Jell-O's invention (or more crucially, the advent of its near-viral advertising) in 1897, Americans have proudly made it their own, studding it with peaches and pimentos, gulping it with vodka and on at least one occasion, forming it into a prize-winning art project containing live but cryogenically slowed-down bugs.

lead_paragraph: Q. What's the difference between U.S.B. and FireWire connections for connecting devices to the computer?
abstract: Q. What's the difference between U.S.B. and FireWire connections for connecting devices to the computer?    A. The main difference right now between U.S.B. (Universal Serial Bus) and FireWire is speed: A device connected to a computer's FireWire port can move a large amount of data much faster than it can through a U.S.B. connection. FireWire can transfer data at a rate up to 400 megabits per second, while the current version of U.S.B. can move data at up to 12 megabits per second.

snippet: New Simputer, Net-linked radically simple portable computer is introduced in India as way to bring computer revolution to third world (The Year in Ideas) (S)
lead_paragraph: The most significant innovation in computer technology in 2001 was not Apple's gleaming titanium PowerBook G4 or Microsoft's Windows XP. It was the Simputer, a Net-linked, radically simple portable computer, intended to bring the computer revolution to the third world. The Simputer, officially unveiled last April and intended for mass production in India next March, is a small hand-held device designed for the rough conditions of rural India. It operates -- without a keyboard -- through touch, sound and simple visual icons. It translates English-language Web sites into local Indian languages, reading the content aloud to illiterate users.

lead_paragraph: Throughout New York City there are new baskets from Africa and Asia, Europe and South America that can hold autumn leaves or freshly picked apples or turn a potted plant into a centerpiece. Above, from left to right: Marguerite Lhuillier's bamboo basket ($98) at the Asia Society; an American wire basket from San Francisco is $98 at the American Folk Art Museum; grass and bark baskets from Mali are $35 to $100 at the Museum for African Art; a yellow wire basket is from South Africa ($79) at the American Museum of Natural History, and colored paper baskets are $65 to $100 at the American Craft Museum. Below, Furniture Co.'s exhibition and sale ''Hand-Woven Baskets,'' through Dec. 1, has artistic baskets (like the tilted one, fourth from right, $2,450) and plain, like the light ones from Colombia on either side for $40 to $75 at 818 Greenwich Street (Jane Street).

snippet: Photos of wide variety of outfits and autumn flowers seen at outdoor greennmarkets in New York City
lead_paragraph: On these crisp fall weekends, the outdoor Greenmarkets are filled with the aroma of fresh apples and the color of autumnal flowers. Their simple pleasures are proving a welcome relief for many trying to return to normal lives amid the daily procession of funerals and memorial services in suburbs and city, where the tolling of bells and the wailing of bagpipes drown out impatient cab horns. The dress code at the markets accommodates a wide spectrum of looks, from country casual to a fashion student's elaborate dress (center, far right). There are shoppers on scooters, Rollerblades and bikes, often with dogs on a leash or in sling carriers. The sight of people with their pets, shoppers buying luscious dahlias and friends happy to see each other safe (Cicely Tyson and John Barry Ryan, top right) helps with healing.

For many years and under several names, this restaurant served Italian food. lead_paragraph: FOR observers of human nature, the end of the year presents a golden opportunity for spotting geeks in their native habitats. Normal people pull tags off gifts; geeks put batteries into them. Normal people spend the week watching movies and reading newly unwrapped books; geeks hook things up to the television. Normal people make up New Year's resolutions like ''Clean the garage,'' ''Learn French'' or ''Get more exercise.'' Geeks pledge to ''Clean up the Web site,'' ''Learn JavaScript'' and ''Get more RAM.''

snippet: Chrysler Design Awards for 2001 will be given to Kathryn Gustafson, Stefan Sagmeister, Susan Kare, Daniel Rozin, Thom Mayne, Robert Mangurian and Mary-Anne Ray; photos (S)
lead_paragraph: The 2001 Chrysler Design Awards will be awarded to seven people on Oct. 17. ''They engage us in a visceral, direct way, and make us curious,'' said Leslie Gill, a Manhattan architect who helped oversee the awards, which are $10,000 each. One winner is Kathryn Gustafson, a landscape architect from Seattle who designed the fountains and the Arthur Ross Terrace at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, below. Another is the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister, who created a 1996 CD cover for Lou Reed, shown above left. ''His work is fresh, personal and emotional,'' said Tod Williams, a juror. Other winners are Susan Kare, who designed icons for the Apple Macintosh; Daniel Rozin, for new interactive technology; Thom Mayne, and the team of Robert Mangurian and Mary-Ann Ray, all architects. ELAINE LOUIE

abstract: U.S. Obtains Concession On Price of Anthrax Drug  The Bush administration said that it had won a price concession from Bayer for its anthrax medicine, Cipro, after the White House threatened to buy generic alternatives instead.    A spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services said that the government had reached an agreement in principle with Bayer to buy the medicine for less than $1 a tablet. The company had planned to charge $1.83 a tablet. [Page B7.]    An administration official said that the government was in talks with seven companies to build a stockpile of smallpox vaccine. [B7.]

People might assume that its creators know exactly what consumers are doing: how much they spend on an average trip to Costco, for example, or on a delivery from the local Thai takeout; how many DVD's they rent or buy; or how much they pay each month for their high-speed Internet service.

snippet: Four Caesars Pocono Resorts will offer 50 percent discounts for additional nights for couples booking Friday and Saturday stays until October 28 (S)
lead_paragraph: The four Caesars Pocono Resorts will take 50 percent off the rate for Thursday or Sunday night when couples book a Friday and Saturday stay, starting this week and continuing through Oct. 28. Prices at the resorts -- Cove Haven, Paradise Stream, Pocono Palace and Brookdale -- include breakfast and dinner and all activities, including golf and tennis, and nightly entertainment; all but Brookdale are couples only. Three nights in a Garden of Eden Apple suite at one of the couples-only resorts, for example, comes to $838 a couple ($670 for Friday and Saturday, $168 for the third night). The suite includes a swimming pool, fireplace and heart-shaped tub. There are some blackout dates, and 6 percent tax and a 15 percent service charge are extra. Information: (800) 233-4141 or on the Internet at www .caesarspoconoresorts.com.

lead_paragraph: CHANDLER-Amy. New York, NY, age 97. On Wednesday, September 26, 2001. Member of the Civic Repertory Theater in the 1930s and the American Repertory Theater in the 1940s. Born in Philadelphia, PA, and came to New York in the 1920s with her friend Thelma Chandler to become a ballerina. Toured with Margaret Webster's company's Bus and Truck tours, which took the theater to towns and cities across the U.S., and the bus and truck tours of Golden Apple, Funny Girl, No Time for Sergeants and Teahouse of the August Moon. Companion to Jane Cowl. Lifelong Democrat. She was a lover and supporter of dogs and the arts, including the New York Metropolitan Opera, the New York City Ballet, as well as the theater and classical music. She was preceded in death by both her parents, her sister Joyce Neely, and her brother Jack Knorr. She is survived by her sister, Violet Brown of Bossier City, LA, and three nieces, Joyce Brown of Nottingham, England, Lois Ennis of Shreveport, LA, and Jill Knorr Smith of New Cumberland, PA. The family requests that donations in memory of Amy be made to the Actors Fund, 729 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY 10019.

lead_paragraph: DEC. 6, DEMRE (NEAR ANTALYA), TURKEY
abstract: DEC. 6, DEMRE (NEAR ANTALYA), TURKEY  St. Nicholas, thought to have been born near here, is celebrated every year on this day with a church service and a scholarly symposium. (212) 687-2194.    DEC. 8 AND 9, SANTA CLAUS, IND.  Christmas in Santa Claus. A parade, music performances, festival of lights, animated displays, costumed characters, Christmas crafts, live Nativity scene. (888) 444-9252.    DEC. 13, STOCKHOLM  Lucia Day. The coronation of Lucia, the bearer of light, is celebrated all over Sweden on the darkest night of the year. On Dec. 13, a young woman is chosen to lead the annual procession of light at the Skansen open air museum. (212) 885-9700.    DEC. 13 TO 16, MIAMI BEACH  Art Basel Miami Beach. Europe's giant art fair in its first venture to the New World. (305) 674-1292.    DEC. 16, BOSTON  Re-enactment of the Boston Tea Party. Starts with a debate at the Old South Meeting House at 5:30; the patriots then march to the Congress Street Bridge and dump the tea. (617) 482-6439.    DEC. 19, LONDON  Christmas Party. Jazz around the Christmas tree, carols around the Kissing Bough (a globe made of willow hoops, mistletoe and apples), gifts from Father Christmas for everyone wearing something red. Victoria and Albert Museum. (44-207) 942-2000.    DEC. 23, OAXACA, MEXICO  Night of the Radishes. Enormous radishes are turned into sculptures, including complete Nativity scenes, and put on display in the zócalo, or town square. (52-951) 648-28.

snippet: Microsoft filed a proposal in federal court today that could remove another of its legal headaches -- more than 100 class-action antitrust suits alleging that it overcharged consumers.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft filed a proposal in federal court on Tuesday that could remove another of its legal headaches -- more than 100 class-action antitrust suits alleging that it overcharged consumers. The proposed deal is an innovative approach to settling a class-action case, since the proceeds would not go to the customers claiming they were overcharged, but to more than 12,500 low-income schools around the country.

lead_paragraph: Visiting Hudson these days means more than picking apples and buying expensive antiques. It is now home to musicians, artists, performance groups and shops selling home furnishings -- many of them on Warren Street between Second and Sixth Streets, near the jumping Red Dot bistro. Partial credit goes to the Fourth Down Association, founded two years ago to increase business below Fifth Street. The Wigsten Farm's five-acre corn maze, above, in Pleasant Valley, about halfway to Hudson, might make a nice stop on the way. It is open from Sept. 1 to Oct. 31, weekdays from 4 to 7 p.m., weekends from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Adults, $7.50; those 5 to 12, $5; under 5, free. Information: www.cornfieldmaze.com or (845) 635-1570.

It is now home to musicians, artists, performance groups and shops selling home furnishings -- many of them on Warren Street between Second and Sixth Streets, near the jumping Red Dot bistro. Partial credit goes to the Fourth Down Association, founded two years ago to increase business below Fifth Street. The Wigsten Farm's five-acre corn maze, above, in Pleasant Valley, about halfway to Hudson, might make a nice stop on the way. It is open from Sept. 1 to Oct. 31, weekdays from 4 to 7 p.m., weekends from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Adults, $7.50; those 5 to 12, $5; under 5, free. Information: www.cornfieldmaze.com or (845) 635-1570.

snippet: Palm Inc will acquire intellectual property of Be, developer of Be operating system, for $11 million in Palm stock (S)
lead_paragraph: Palm, the maker of hand-held computers and the Palm operating system, said yesterday that it would acquire the intellectual property of Be, developer of the Be operating system. The purchase price was $11 million, to be paid in Palm stock. Palm also offered jobs to Be's engineers for its software engineering group. Jean-Louis Gassée, Be's chief executive, who once led Apple Computer's product development efforts, will become a temporary adviser to Palm. Separately, Palm said that Alan Kessler, general manager of the company's platform solutions group, had resigned. Until a replacement is found, Eric Benhamou, Palm's chairman, will run the operation, which is responsible for developing and licensing the Palm operating system. Palm, based in Santa Clara, Calif., recently spun off the platform solutions group into a wholly owned subsidiary. Mr. Kessler declined to give any reason for his resignation.
abstract: Palm Inc will acquire intellectual property of Be, developer of Be operating system, for $11 million in Palm stock (S)

snippet: Ingrid Sischy article on artist Jeff Koons, who offers his sexual interpretation of grilled cheese sandwich; recipes; photo (M) (special section, Fashions of The Times Fall 2001) (part 2 of 2-part section)
lead_paragraph: ''Did you know that the largest grilled cheese sandwich on record weighed more than 300 pounds?'' Jeff Koons asks. ''But,'' the artist continues, ''the sandwich was disqualified from 'The Guinness Book of World Records' because they used multiple slices of bread instead of baking just two enormous pieces for the outside.'' Koons isn't usually a trivia expert on food, but grilled cheese sandwiches are a whole other thing. For Proust it was a cookie that conjured remembrances of things past; for Koons it is that slightly salty, very buttery taste of pan-fried bread and oozing melted cheese that makes him feel as if he's gone back home to his 50's childhood in York, Pa.

snippet: Editorial says Microsoft's plan to give away $1 billion worth of computer technology to nation's poorest schools is hard to criticize, but may not be proper settlement to end class-action antitrust lawsuits; urges Federal Dist Judge J Frederick Mo...
lead_paragraph: Microsoft's plan to give away $1 billion worth of computer technology to the nation's poorest schools is hard to attack. Nobody is against improving technological resources for needy youngsters. But it may not be a proper settlement to end class-action antitrust suits. Federal District Judge J. Frederick Motz ought to push the software company and the plaintiffs' lawyers in these cases to substantially alter the terms of the settlement. Otherwise, he should consider rejecting it.

lead_paragraph: There's a little takeout food shop in every town that's always got exactly what you're in the mood for. At least, there should be. In Hoboken, Anthony David's is that place. Once a 1930's grocery, the spot, run by Anthony and Liz Pino since 1998, has the original tin ceilings and hardwood floors. Mornings start with muffins, croissants and bagels, and coffee brewed from a special blend of dark-roasted Costa Rican Tico beans ($1.25 a large cup), strong and aromatic, but low in acidity. Midday pangs can be quieted with Anthony's sandwiches (all $5.50). The grilled pepper chicken sandwich, layered with goat cheese, caramelized onions, tomato, arugula and a tangy balsamic aïoli, is a feast between slices of whole-grain bread. There are also a fresh mozzarella and tomato sandwich, dressed with basil pesto on a rosemary ciabatta, and a French chicken salad sandwich with Granny Smith apples and Swiss cheese. The shop can also help you impress your friends with a fancy ''homemade'' dinner. It might start with golden crab cakes, or a bowl of Mediterranean chopped salad studded with feta, roasted red peppers, and chickpeas. For the main course, there is pepper-crusted ahi tuna with soba noodles; spicy lamb sausage tossed with fresh herbs and tomatoes over pappardelle; or messy, juicy, barbecued pork chops (all entrees $9.75 to $22 a pound). Remember to hide the takeout containers.

snippet: Rutgers University Cooperative Extension Service, citing good rainfall, reports many New Jersey crops are doing exceptionally well this year (S)
lead_paragraph: Many New Jersey crops are doing exceptionally well this year despite a slow start to the season, according to agriculture agents with the Rutgers University Cooperative Extension Service. Peaches in particular are doing well because of rainfall at the right times, said Win Cowgill, an Extension Service fruit expert. Apples, which are not ripe as yet, also are doing well, he said. For the state's vegetable crops, such as peppers, corn, tomatoes and lima beans, the year started slow with dry, cold weather but has improved since then. The only sour note in the mix is blueberries, which are off normal production levels by 30 percent in some regions , although the reason for the underyield is not known, said Nicholi Vorsa, director of the Philip E. Marucci Center for Blueberry and Cranberry Research with Rutgers. Karen DeMasters

lead_paragraph: Fed Cuts Interest Rates For Seventh Time This Year
abstract: Fed Cuts Interest Rates For Seventh Time This Year  Citing a persistently weak business environment at home and slowing economic growth abroad, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point and signaled that its campaign to avert a recession is probably not yet over.    The rate cut was the seventh this year and brought the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks to 3.5 percent. It has been one of the most concentrated periods of monetary policy easing on record. [Page A1.]

lead_paragraph: Celebration in Stamford
abstract: Celebration in Stamford      Kwanzaa, the seven-day observance of the African-American heritage of family and community spirit was founded in 1966 by Dr. Maulana Karenga, head of the Black Studies Department at California State University in Long Beach. It has become a nationwide celebration that starts Dec. 26.    Josephine Fulcher-Anderson, co-founder of the Stamford Kwanzaa Association, said, ''Now more than ever it's important to gather in celebration of life, heritage and family -- for all races to come together in support of our community and nation.''

snippet: Regina Schrambling reviews Hudson House, restaurant in Cold Spring, NY; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: EVER since I spent a summer -- and a small fortune -- exploring the Hudson Valley, the Hudson House in Cold Spring has been my preferred antidote to major stress. The town itself is the most charming spot on the river, picturesque but completely real, and the inn, built in 1832, is the best place I know for an overnight respite. Getting there is also half the healing: Cold Spring is a world away from Manhattan intensity but easy to reach in a little over an hour if I leave the driving to Metro-North, whose tracks hug the river with dazzling views all the way.

snippet: INTERNET NAPSTER COURT DATE The date has been set for the next legal proceeding in the matter of the record companies versus Napster . On March 2, at 10 a.m., all sides are scheduled to appear at a hearing that may determine when Napster, which pe...
lead_paragraph: INTERNET NAPSTER COURT DATE The date has been set for the next legal proceeding in the matter of the record companies versus Napster . On March 2, at 10 a.m., all sides are scheduled to appear at a hearing that may determine when Napster, which permits users to exchange music free over the Internet, will cease to exist in its current incarnation. The hearing is before Chief Judge Marilyn Patel of the United States District Court in San Francisco. Judge Patel issued a preliminary injunction in July ordering Napster to stop permitting the exchange of works whose copyrights are held by the major record labels. Last week, a federal appeals court affirmed much of Judge Patel's ruling but ordered her to narrow its scope. Napster has said that depending on the scope of the injunction it may be forced to close. Matt Richtel (NYT)

lead_paragraph: BLUE DIARY
abstract: BLUE DIARY  By Alice Hoffman  303 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.       In her latest novel Alice Hoffman writes fulsomely of family reunions and blueberry pie, of goldenrod beside roadsides, of fluttering sparrows and cooing doves, of how ''lilies that bloom in daylight lose their short-lived petals as soon as moonlight begins to spill from the sky,'' of the way ''the first radiant bands of light break open the leaden blue sky of morning.'' And that's only on Page 231. Throughout ''Blue Diary,'' her use of natural and horticultural detail is so indiscriminate as to go beyond the atmospheric and actually choke the novel. Whenever the author says anything once, she lets the flora and fauna say it three more times, to the point where nobody says anything much at all.

snippet: Article describes optimism and resilience of many of New York's elderly, some of whom offer their views on terrorism crisis; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THEY remember the good times that came before Sept. 11, and they remember the bad times, too. They lighted candles during blackouts, sold apples on street corners during the Depression and went through air raid drills during World War II. But most of all, when they look back over their many decades in the city, they simply remember change and how it chisels away at life.

lead_paragraph: A Strong Rally in Stocks On Positive Profit Reports
abstract: A Strong Rally in Stocks On Positive Profit Reports  A handful of positive earnings reports set off a broad-based rally on Wall Street, sending the Dow Jones industrial average up 1.3 percent as investors grew more confident about companies' prospects in the months ahead.     The Dow rose 134.27 points, to 10,606.39. Broader stock indicators also advanced. The Nasdaq composite index rose 1.9 percent, gaining 38.20 points, to 2,067.32, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 11.99 points, or 1 percent, to 1,214.44. [Page C12.]

snippet: Connecticut State Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities investigates charges of sexual harassment brought by 18 women employed at Lyman Farm, a tourist site in Middleton, against manager, Frank Cavaliere (S)
lead_paragraph: Women who work at a popular attraction in Middlefield have complained to a state agency that the company tolerated a male manager's persistent sexual harassment and promoted him despite their complaints. Eighteen women left their jobs at the tourist site, Lyman Farm, known for apple-picking and pony rides, to protest the company's response, said Linda Cameron, a former customer service manager. The State Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities said it was investigating. The accused manager, Frank Cavaliere, has since left Lyman and could not be reached for comment.

snippet: Pumpkin, apple and other autumnal-themed events are scheduled in several areas of Pennsylvania; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Apples and pumpkins are two of the autumnal themes at upcoming events in Pennsylvania. The three-day Applefest in Franklin, on the Allegheny River about 70 miles north of Pittsburgh, is held this Friday through Sunday. Originally a pie-baking contest, it now includes arts and crafts, puppet shows, tours of Tiffany windows and horse-drawn buggy rides. Activities will be staged throughout downtown each day, starting at 10 a.m. Information: (888) 547-2377, www.franklin-pa.org.

lead_paragraph: Best Bet
abstract: Best Bet      Playing Bach, Beethoven, Borodin and Joel -- yes, Billy Joel, the pianist Richard Joo on Saturday opens the new season at the Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University. The world premieres of works by Mr. Joel include pieces featured on ''Fantasties and Delusions,'' a new recording that Sony and Columbia Records will release in a few days. Like the previously heard ''Soliloquy,'' the new ''pieces by B. Joel'' were arranged by Mr. Joo. The concert is at 8 p.m. in the center's Recital Hall (631) 632-2787.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK
abstract: NEW YORK    MANHATTAN: WOMAN PUSHED ONTO TRACKS  A 59-year-old woman remained hospitalized last night after a stranger pushed her onto the subway tracks on Saturday, the authorities said. The woman, whose identity was not immediately released, told the police that she was waiting for the northbound No. 1 train at Seventh Avenue and 14th Street about 7 p.m. when a man argued with her and pushed her onto the tracks. There was no train on the tracks, but the woman suffered head injuries and was taken to the Manhattan campus of St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, where she was in stable condition yesterday, the police said. Two police officers at the station rescued the woman and arrested a suspect, Eric Chin, 21, of Las Vegas, who was charged with assault and reckless endangerment.   Sherri Day (NYT)    BRONX: FERRER URGES AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS  Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and a Democratic candidate for mayor, unveiled a plan yesterday to reduce juvenile crime by expanding after-school and weekend academic and recreational programs at city middle schools. The programs would run weekdays from 3 to 6 p.m., as well as on Saturdays and Sundays, and cost an estimated $100 million a year. About 200,000 children would participate. The programs would require at least $45 million a year in new city money, Mr. Ferrer said.   Eric Lipton (NYT)

lead_paragraph: In 1949, when I was 8, my mother, my two sisters and I sailed here from Taiwan to join my father. When I started school two months later, I didn't know a word of English. I sat in my third-grade class and copied everything from the blackboard into my notebook. My father would come home at night after working two or three jobs and translate for me.

snippet: Some desserts for calorie-phobic restaurant diners in Manhattan noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)
lead_paragraph: Fashion-savvy restaurants have taken to matching courses as if they were clothes, offering desserts that echo ingredients used in main dishes. To tempt the calorie-phobic, pastry chefs are leaning almost as heavily on the savory as they are on the sweet -- particularly in the Flatiron district, where throngs of thin and thinner would-be models can be seen dining. (Which is what they want.) Patria offers poached pears with a gazpacho sorbet (above) made of tomato juice, cucumber juice, red wine vinegar and sugar ($9); a stiff goat cheese custard ($9); and a strawberry Basque cake ($10) with red pepper sauce and camomile ice cream. At Beppe, after-dinner brittles made of pork, rosemary and basil are the confection of choice. And Lotus offers a napoleon of almond ice cream, green grapes, honey, lavender and white truffle sauce ($8). ''These days, people tend to be very health conscious,'' said Alex Asteínza, the pastry chef at Patria, ''so I try to use sugar as a seasoning rather than as a whole flavor.'' For fall, he intends to add a new savory dessert: an apple empanada served with blue cheese and a toasted bacon salad. Bacon, now that's healthy.
abstract: Some desserts for calorie-phobic restaurant diners in Manhattan noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)

snippet: Somewhere, Norton Simon, the pioneering industrialist who died in 1993, must be proud. In the 1940's, 50's and 60's, Mr. Simon turned a small investment in a failing orange-juice bottling plant into one of the first multinational consumer products...
lead_paragraph: Somewhere, Norton Simon, the pioneering industrialist who died in 1993, must be proud. In the 1940's, 50's and 60's, Mr. Simon turned a small investment in a failing orange-juice bottling plant into one of the first multinational consumer products conglomerates, with well-known properties like Hunt-Wesson Foods, McCall's, Max Factor, Avis and Canada Dry. Then he amassed a renowned art collection, with masterworks by the likes of Raphael, Cézanne, Picasso and Matisse, now housed in the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, Calif. In both pursuits, he was the quintessential value hunter, searching for undermanaged or underappreciated companies and art.

snippet: Verlyn Klinkenborg The Rural Life editorial on why he raises pigs
lead_paragraph: For the past three months, I have been thinking about raising pigs. Ask anyone who knows me. Sooner or later, the conversation turns to raising pigs. I have a small shelf full of books whose titles include the words ''pigs'' and ''successful.'' I have even sold, as futures, the four quarters of a prospective pig to friends who have decided to humor me. At this moment in Montgomery County, N.Y., a sow is pregnant, or ''in pig'' as the pig farmers say, with a litter of piglets from which I hope to take two in May, when they should weigh about 40 pounds apiece. The sow and the boar who bred her are Tamworths, an uncommon, endangered breed, lean, gingery, bacon types, good foragers, good mothers.

snippet: Impact of Sept 11 terrorist attacks is being measured and counted in various ways, from sales of television sets, airline industry layoffs, crime to soaring number of prescriptions for antidepressant and antianxiety drugs; photos; chart (L)
lead_paragraph: MEASURING the impact of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon has become a relentless exercise among economists, politicians, journalists, historians and everyday people. In its simplest terms, taking numeric stock of damages and changes is the necessary stuff of recovery --the basis for making decisions on the allocation of funds, the adjustment of interest rates, or at a more mundane level, whether to take that holiday trip to the Big Apple. But the counting ritual is also therapeutic -- a means for getting a handle on events that may still feel wildly out of control.
abstract: Impact of Sept 11 terrorist attacks is being measured and counted in various ways, from sales of television sets, airline industry layoffs, crime to soaring number of prescriptions for antidepressant and antianxiety drugs; photos; chart (L)

snippet: Ali Lozoff letter reports that staying at Ian Schrager's hotels is like spending time in pleasant dream (S)
lead_paragraph: I've had the pleasure of staying at one of Schrager's hotels (the Mondrian in Los Angeles) and of looking in at two others (the Delano in Miami Beach and St. Martin's Lane in London). For me, they were like spending time in a very pleasant dream. Lots of white expanses broken up by whimsical touches -- vases full of giant lollipops, a large-scale chessboard, fresh green apples in every room, music playing in the pool. The only negatives we experienced were that, after a fabulous dessert and coffee at St. Martin's Lane, we tried to take a photo to capture the moment and were rudely told to stop. When we apologized and said we weren't photographing the hotel but ourselves, we were threatened with a lawsuit and shown the door. A similar thing happened in Los Angeles. Perhaps the recent struggles with the W chain have caused this paranoia. But not everyone is a corporate spy, Mr. Schrager.

snippet: When prosciutto di Parma ham is boned before it is sold, it is pressed into a flattened shape, resulting in the typical elongated slice.
lead_paragraph: When prosciutto di Parma ham is boned before it is sold, it is pressed into a flattened shape, resulting in the typical elongated slice. But there is another kind of prosciutto, called rotondo, with a fuller, rounded slice that results from rolling and tying the boned ham. It has the usual nut-sweet flavor but is a little moister. Rotondo is now available at Agata & Valentina, where Eric Menal, the deli manager, sells it for $17.99 a pound. It is also sold at Citarella for $19.96 a pound.

lead_paragraph: Q. I am running Windows Me and I installed the Zone Labs firewall. The firewall keeps telling me that ''BackWeb.exe'' wants access to the Internet, and I keep telling it no. Is BackWeb a good thing or a bad thing? Just what is it?
abstract: Q.  I am running Windows Me and I installed the Zone Labs firewall. The firewall keeps telling me that ''BackWeb.exe'' wants access to the Internet, and I keep telling it no. Is BackWeb a good thing or a bad thing? Just what is it?    A.  The program that keeps knocking to get out through your firewall, BackWeb.exe, is designed to detect a computer's Internet connection and then download any software updates or patches that the computer might need.

lead_paragraph: IT'S 10 a.m. on the Quai des Belges in the Vieux Port of Marseille. Small fishing boats pull into the harbor. Earlier arrivals have already set up their makeshift stands to display their catch. There are cuttlefish in a puddle of their ink; hideous monkfish, sole, red mullets, rascasse (scorpion fish), conger eel, sea urchins. At the stand of a boat called Patricia, the still lively daurade grise (gray sea bream) thwack their tails, splashing the housewives and restaurateurs who assess them with the sharp eyes of experts.
abstract: Jacqueline Friedrich reviews restaurants in Marseilles; photos (M)

The little lamplit cobblestone streets sound like lanes in a fairy tale: Rue Git-le-Coeur (Here Lies the Heart Street), Rue du Chat Qui Pêche (Street of the Cat Who Fishes), Rue des Mauvais Garçons (Bad Boys' Street). And the money seems like fairyland money.

snippet: Julia Reed Food column on cooking chicken or shrimp curry; some other curry dishes noted; recipes; photo (L)
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, the most exotic thing anybody could possibly serve was a chicken or shrimp curry. This was in the 60's, in the South, long before we had ever heard of red or green Thai curries. And certainly long before home cooks thought to make their own freshly roasted and hand-ground blends of spices. A ''curry'' was a dish made with marigold yellow curry powder straight from the jar, blended with heavy cream or coconut milk and served with at least a dozen little bowls of delicious condiments ranging from chutney to crumbled bacon and chopped bananas. Its foreign associations put it in the same exalted league of dinner party fare as, say, chicken Kiev, but its flavors were more nuanced and its presentation was far more festive.
abstract: Julia Reed Food column on cooking chicken or shrimp curry; some other curry dishes noted; recipes; photo (L)

lead_paragraph: THE desire to cook a large, bountiful meal for family and friends is something that probably does not come to you every night, or even most nights. It is more likely a whimsical urge, something that hits you and is like a trance, tempting you to pull out every last pot and page through your cookbooks. It comes at the holidays, on vacations, at moments of procrastination or when times are difficult. It is an urge that should be embraced, for we all know that entertaining at home has become rare, if not rarefied.

byline.original: By Jean Lemierre, International Herald Tribune

lead_paragraph: PLAYING the Marquis de Sade has to be an emotional high for an actor, and Geoffrey Rush revels in the challenge in Philip Kaufman's harrowing drama QUILLS (2000). Joaquin Phoenix is the abbé in charge of Sade at Charenton Asylum, and he does not approve of his prisoner's literary work (''It's nothing but an encyclopedia of perversions''). Michael Caine, the new doctor sent to advise the abbé, is busy locking up his new under-age wife (Amelia Warner), fresh from the convent (''She is a rare bird; I intend to keep her cared''). Kate Winslet is the chambermaid who's sneaking the marquis's new work, page by page, to his publisher. This is a wrenchingly violent film, but not in the usual ways -- Tuesday at 7:45 p.m on Cinemax.

BARNABY J. FEDER

abstract: Adapted from a successful one-man show, "Jails, Hospitals and Hip-Hop" presents the performance artist Danny Hoch as nine characters, counting himself. The tall, pale Mr. Hoch, who bears a haunting resemblance in looks and speech to Huntz Hall of the Bowery Boys, is a gifted performer who uses his mastery of rap rhythms to invest his characters with remarkable energy and definition.  The multiethnic, cross-cultural world of hip-hop is Mr. Hoch's home base, and although he is of no identifiable ethnicity, he slips easily into the speech patterns of the black, Latino and white ethnic characters he portrays. — Dave Kehr

lead_paragraph: SANDLER-Herman, 57. Loving husband of Suki, devoted father of Pamela, Gillian and Jordana, role model and mentor to hundreds of young people. You encouraged us to take risks and gave us innumerable opportunities to follow our dreams, cheering us on as we learned to impact the world as you did so powerfully. You will always remain our awesome inspiration. We love you, Suki, Pamela, Gillian and Jordana. In lieu of flowers, gifts honoring Herman may be made to any of the following organizations: American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, The Rain Forest Foundation, The Perlman Music Program, Carnegie Hall, or UJA Federation of NY.
abstract: SANDLER-Herman, 57. Loving husband of Suki, devoted father of Pamela, Gillian and Jordana, role model and mentor to hundreds of young people. You encouraged us to take risks and gave us innumerable opportunities to follow our dreams, cheering us on as we learned to impact the world as you did so powerfully. You will always remain our awesome inspiration. We love you, Suki, Pamela, Gillian and Jordana. In lieu of flowers, gifts honoring Herman may be made to any of the following organizations: American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, The Rain Forest Foundation, The Perlman Music Program, Carnegie Hall, or UJA Federation of NY.    SANDLER-Herman. It was Herman Sandler's altruism and generosity that first brought him into Sting's and my lives and the life of the Rain Forest Foundation. Every year he would come to the annual fund-raising concert at Carnegie Hall, bringing with him a huge party of colleagues and family, and donating very substantial sums to our cause. His support of my work extended to smaller projects, such as the Tibetan Peace Garden in London, and he championed my endeavors with huge interest, support and indefatigable energy. He was a joy to be with socially, a charismatic personality exuding a sense of fun and enthusiasm for life that shone from his boyish eyes. I will miss his company, I will miss trying to amuse him just to hear his wonderful infectious laughter. He imbued New York with his vital life force, and it's a smaller apple without him. We will always remember him. Trudie Styler and Sting    SANDLER-Herman S. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the tragic passing of our devoted congregant, Herman Sandler. We extend to his wife, Suki, his daughters, Pamela, Jordana, Gillian, his mother & the entire family, our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President    SANDLER-Herman. To our best friend who filled us with a passion for living and the inspiration to carry on. We will always remember and love you. Melvin, Helen and Jack Heller    SANDLER-Herman. We will miss you, your knowledge, enthusiasm, generosity, humor, and most of all your friendship. Our deepest sympathies to Suki and the family. Jackie and Mort Ackerman    SANDLER-Herman. A great friend will be missed immeasurably. Strength to Suki, Pam, Gillian and Jordana. Eleanor Heyman Rodney Propp

snippet: advï
lead_paragraph: In their low-slung Denver living room last fall, Robert Schneider and Hilarie Sidney were talking about what it means for musicians to sell out. Robert sat on the carpet, jittery and animated under a wisp of sandy hair; his wife, Hilarie, who was eight months pregnant with their first child, offered cookies. The day the Beach Boys sold ''Good Vibrations'' for a soft-drink ad, they agreed, was one of betrayal and ruin. ''That was the Beach Boys at their wildest and most psychedelic,'' Robert says. ''For a long time after that, it was hard for me to take the song out of the Sunkist commercial.''

lead_paragraph: Museum shops, long destinations for gift shoppers, now cater to holiday hosts, too, with distinctive dinnerware being the latest offering. AsiaStore, the shop in the newly refurbished Asia Society (725 Park Avenue at 70th Street), sells Asianera, its exclusive pattern in white bone china with patterned rims. A 10-inch dinner plate is $28.50; the 7-inch salad or dessert plate with an underwater scene, $16.50; a soup bowl, $15; and a mug, $18. The Neue Galerie New York, a museum of German and Austrian Art (1048 Fifth Avenue at 86th Street) has stoneware dishes, center, inspired by the Austrian designer Koloman Moser of the Wiener Werkstätte. The white plates have demure blue-and-white checked rims. The dinner plate is $48; a salad plate, $18; the soup bowl, $24. For more casual entertaining, the Metropolitan Museum Shops sell tin plates that are exact reproductions of blue and white English Staffordshire. A set of four is $30. For store locations: (800) 662-3397.

snippet: Photos of fruit-patterned bikini bathing suits (Pulse column) (S)
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian-inspired tropicalia on last year's swimwear have been replaced this summer by suits bearing fruit. Following the lead of the sellout Chloé maillot, with a pineapple strategically silk-screened on the bottom, designers are raiding the orchards and splashing their graphic harvest on bikinis, one-pieces, coverups and beach gear. In a three-cherry jackpot, bikinis by Shoshanna (bottoms for $50 and halter-style tops for $57 at Olive & Bette), Moschino ($130 at Saks Fifth Avenue) and Marc by Marc Jacobs ($158 at Barneys New York) all put the spotlight on cherries. Rosa Cha offers a white bikini ornamented with four puffy strawberry appliqués ($110), as well as a black one printed with pears, apples and bananas ($130, both at Bergdorf Goodman). And for those who could not get their hands on the popular Chloé pineapple number, Chloé's coverup T-shirts are available at Saks Fifth Avenue ($615), with butterflied sleeves and a large image of a single upright banana curving to point at the décolletage. Now that's fresh produce.
abstract: Photos of fruit-patterned bikini bathing suits (Pulse column) (S)

lead_paragraph: WATTS-Charles Henry II. September 27, 2001; Freedom, NH. Charles H. Watts II of Freedom, New Hampshire and Boston, Massachusetts, died unexpectedly of a heart attack yesterday at his farm in New Hampshire. He was the beloved husband of Patricia McQuillen Watts. Born in 1926 in Bronxville, New York, Mr. Watts was the only child of Charles H. and Mabel L. Watts. He married Patricia Dorothy McQuillen, also of Bronxville, in 1951. After completing his Ph.D. in American Literature at Brown University in 1953, he became an Assistant Professor of English at Brown and was later named Dean of the College. In 1963, at the age of 37, he was named President of Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania, where he served for twelve years, leading the school through an important period of change and growth. Following his time at Bucknell, Mr. Watts returned to Brown University to help launch a major capital campaign. He then joined Beneficial Financial Corporation (later acquired by Household Finance) in the position of General Director. Mr. Watts, whose father, Charles H. Watts, was one of Beneficial's original founders, was also a member of the Beneficial Board from 1959 until 1998. He received honorary degrees from Franklin College (D.Lit., 1965), Dickenson School of Law (L.L.D., 1968), Alderson Broaddus College (H.H.D., 1969), Brown University (L.L.D., 1975), and Bucknell University (L.H.D., 1979). Throughout his career, Mr. Watts served on numerous academic, corporate and civic boards. He was a member of the board of the Riverdale School (1959-1974), Bucknell University (1964-1976), the Peddie School (1971-1985), and St. John's College (1976-present). He was also an active board member of the John Carter Brown Library at Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island. In addition to the library, he was deeply committed to Trinity Church, in Boston, and the Society for the Preservation of New Hampshire Forests in Concord, New Hampshire. Mr. Watts was an avid conservationist throughout his life and worked with both the Audubon and New Hampshire Forest societies to preserve the natural environment in New Hampshire. Mr. Watts and his wife opened High Meadow Farms, in Freedom, New Hampshire, in the mid-fifties with the late Percy Taylor, also of Freedom. The farm, which operated commercially for nearly forty years, sold eggs, apples, wood and hay. Mr. Watts is survived by his wife, Patricia, and their three children: Katharine L. Watts and her son Cooper; Caroline W. Collins and her husband Peter and their children Dylan and Abigail; Charles H. Watts III and his wife Holly and their children Samuel, Isabel, and Isaac. Services will be held at Trinity Church, in Boston, on Wednesday, October 3, 2001, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, offerings will be gratefully accepted by Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston, MA 02116; or by the John Carter Brown Library, Brown University, Providence, RI 02906.

snippet: Andrea Strong reviews Charlie's Cafe, Cheese Shop and Farm Market in Normandy Beach, NJ; logo (M)
lead_paragraph: If the staff don't know your name when you walk into Charlie's, a family-run cafe, cheese shop and farm stand in Normandy Beach, you can be sure they'll know it (and how you like your eggs) by the time you leave. The husband and wife team of Tom and Teri Lightner opened this seaside staple in 1979 when they inherited it from Charlie, Tom's father. Fresh Jersey ingredients have been their focus ever since. In the bright tented cafe, mornings start with homemade muffins packed with Jersey blueberries ($2), thick slices of apple-cinnamon-stuffed French toast ($5.95), Belgian waffles crowned with whipped cream and summer berries ($5.95), or fluffy omelets filled with your choice of cheese and farm stand vegetables ($4.25 to $5.50). Best of all, the warm staff keeps the freshly brewed coffee coming, with no need to ask for refills. If a sit-down breakfast is not your thing, head over to the cheese shop (stocked with 500 varieties) for a bagel and a schmear. Choose from a dozen cheese spreads (all made there) like Garden Vegetable, a blend of cream cheese, cheddar, peppers, scallions, and radishes, or Tijuana Hot, a blend of yellow cheddar and jalapeño, which will wake you up as surely as the coffee. For lunch, sandwiches like prosciutto, roasted peppers, and fresh mozzarella ($6.95) share menu space with juicy burgers. And for the bikinied crowd, there's a good selection of salads ($6.99 to $9.95). There's also a ''Light Nibbles'' menu with impressive little bites like bruschetta, crab cakes, prosciutto-and-melon wraps, and a nice fruit and cheese board. This is far from shore grub. Unfortunately, T Tom passed away last year, but left behind a legacy for all enjoy, season after season. Andrea Strong
abstract: Andrea Strong reviews Charlie's Cafe, Cheese Shop and Farm Market in Normandy Beach, NJ; logo (M)

lead_paragraph: Pink and white dogwoods, purple crab apple blossoms and golden daffodils are abloom in the garden at Drumthwacket in Princeton, the governor's official residence. ''It does seem to be a very lush year,'' said Lisa Paine, executive director of the Drumthwacket Foundation. To take advantage of the seasonal beauty, special garden tours will be offered this month only, starting with an open house today, 11 to 2 p.m. It is one of the only Sundays during the year when the house is open to visitors. There will be floral arrangements by the Garden Club of New Jersey along with music by Purcell, Mozart and Handel played by Hopewell Valley Regional Schools students. The battleship New Jersey silver will also be on display. Other garden programs will be on Wednesday, May 16 and May 23. Margo Nash

lead_paragraph: RUDIN-Lewis. The faculty and staff of the Center for Complementary and Integrative Medicine of Weill Medical College extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Lewis Rudin. We thank Mr. Rudin for his generous support and his many years of service to our community. All New Yorkers will miss his vision for New York City. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Rudin family at this very difficult time. Mary Charlson, M.D., Exec Dir Mitchell Gaynor, M.D., Med Dir
abstract: RUDIN-Lewis. The faculty and staff of the Center for Complementary and Integrative Medicine of Weill Medical College extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Lewis Rudin. The Board and staff of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, mourn the passing of Lewis Rudin. He was ever a ''Good Scout,'' from his early days at Ten Mile River Scout Camps, to his adulthood as a friend and sustainer of scouting and all of New York City. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Rudin family. John F. McGillicuddy, President Daniel R. Gasparo, Scout Executive     RUDIN-Lewis. Appeal of Conscience Foundation mourns the loss of a friend whose generosity and dedication was felt in the Big Apple he loved. To his wife Rachel, his brother Jack, his children and the entire family, our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier President H. E. Archbishop Khajag Barsamian, Vice President Rev. Joseph O'Hare, S.J. Vice President     RUDIN-Lewis. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Lew Rudin, a true friend to our company and role model for our industry. Lew's influence and friendship enriched us all and will inspire us to help continue his work of assuring New York City's position as the Capital of the World. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family. Scott Rechler, Philip Waterman III Rechson Associates Realty Corp     RUDIN-Lewis. We shall forever miss your comradery, wisdom, strength, leadership, guidance and love. As the sea that started our family, your spirit will live on in it forever. You were always there for us and we will always be there for your family, to whom we extend our deepest and sincerest condolences. Suzy and Kenny     RUDIN-Lewis. We mourn the passing of our dear friend, an exemplary family member and great New Yorker. To Rachel, Jack, children and grandchildren we send our deepest sympathies. The Shubert Organization Gerald Schoenfeld, Chairman Philip Smith, President Robert Wankel, Exec. V.P. and its Board of Directors     RUDIN-Lewis. Our Nation, our state, our city and most important, our family, have all been blessed by Lew's involvement in our lives. Our thoughts and affection for you, will always be reflected in our love for your entire family. Joan, Bob, Jamie, Steve, Laurie Tisch Sussman and Jonathan Tisch

snippet: Pastry chef Michel Florance, who owns wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake souffles or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party; photos (S)
lead_paragraph: This pastry chef makes house calls. Michel Floranc, above, who owns Toute Sweet, a wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake souffles or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party, or he will be there simply to put his desserts on plates with his own personal touch. In his repertory are excellent thin-crusted apple galettes seasoned with a whiff of cinnamon and decorated with a tangle of dried apple peel (left); sumptuous little chestnut cakes; classics like eclairs; and cakes for special occasions. Desserts prepared and put on plates in your home start at $8 a portion (no minimum number of guests), plus a charge of $25 an hour for the chef. Without Mr. Floranc's participation, the pastries start at $1.50 each for miniature tartlets and eclairs. Apple galettes are $7 each, and most large tarts and cakes, which serve 6 to 12, are $25 to $45. Delivery is available in Manhattan for orders of at least $40; (718) 429-8714.
