snippet: M H Reed reviews Caffe Regatta Oyster Bar & Grill in Pelham, NY; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: AS the heat of the season intensifies and respite at the shore seems weeks away, those of us detained on shimmering pavements can get a taste of the sea on main street here at Caffe Regatta. This new kid in town has arrived not a moment too soon. Its very name evokes full sails, swift boats and cool breezes; but more than that, anyone with a hankering for fresh fish will be accommodated here. Arrive hungry. Most portions are huge and easily shared.

lead_paragraph: EITHER P. G. Wodehouse, the humorist, or Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court justice, I felt certain, wrote about this incident involving a caddie: ''Mitchell addressed his ball. He swung up, and then, from immediately behind him came a sudden sharp crunching sound. I looked quickly in the direction whence it came. Mitchell's caddie, with a glassy look in his eyes, was gnawing a large apple. Even as I breathed a silent prayer, down came the driver and the ball, with a terrible slice on it, hit the side of the hill and bounded into the ravine.''

abstract: IN the best sense of the phrase, Deborah Stanton has been around the block a few times. She has cooked with Wayne Nish at March, James Chew at Vong and Don Pintabona at Tribeca Grill. She was the chef at Mika, a Japanese fusion restaurant in SoHo, and in the mid-1990's she was the head chef at the Galaxy on Irving Place, where she experimented successfully with dishes like clams in hemp broth. snippet: This gorgeous tart has three primary layers: an olive purée, an onion jam and sliced red potatoes.
lead_paragraph: This gorgeous tart has three primary layers: an olive purée, an onion jam and sliced red potatoes. Since you're working with dough and the ingredients need to be cold, the onion jam -- the only ingredient cooked before baking -- has to be prepared first so it has time to cool. We're suggesting the same dough as the one used in our apple tart lesson, but any dough base will tend to work, including filo dough or even pizza dough. The reason the tart is cooked in two stages is to allow the garlic, thyme and goat cheese to cook less to avoid burning them.

lead_paragraph: Craft is a work-ethic restaurant. As the name artfully, or craftily, suggests, the cooking concentrates on fundamentals, with ingredients subjected to the bare minimum of manipulation. That's part of the idea. The other part is the job set aside for diners, who must throw aside their passive role and join Craft's chef and owner, Tom Colicchio, in the joyous job of building a meal.
abstract: Craft is a work-ethic restaurant. As the name artfully, or craftily, suggests, the cooking concentrates on fundamentals, with ingredients subjected to the bare minimum of manipulation. That's part of the idea. The other part is the job set aside for diners, who must throw aside their passive role and join Craft's chef and owner, Tom Colicchio, in the joyous job of building a meal.    Instead of dishes, Craft submits a list of components that can be combined in many ways. These are divided into two main categories, fish (and shellfish) and meat, which are subdivided by means of preparation like roasted or braised. Diners choose a main ingredient, then create a dish by adding choices from supplementary categories like vegetables and potatoes, which like meat and fish are grouped on the menu according to cooking method.

snippet: Bruce Weber reviews Hello Herman, John Buffalo Mailer play directed by Thomas Kail; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: John Buffalo Mailer, a 23-year-old playwright, seems to have inherited the family hubris; that's a good thing, more or less. When not much older, his father yes, Norman published ''The Naked and the Dead'' and began his career as a self-appointed American mentor. And whether or not you think Mailer père was up to the task, he never shied from it. Now his son, a recent graduate of Wesleyan University and very possibly the smartest kid in theater class, has written a play that is a chip off the old block -- at least in terms of authorial bravado.

lead_paragraph: FOLLOW THAT SHIP  Cunard is offering round-trip air fare and savings up to 50 percent on six one-way cruises from January through April 2002 as the QE2 makes its way around the world. A 14-day trip leaves New York Jan. 7 for Los Angeles, with a Panama Canal transit; rates start at $1,998 a person, double occupancy. On Jan. 21, the ship leaves Los Angeles on a 22-day voyage to Sydney, with fares starting at $3,298 a person, double. The longest segment is a 26-day trip from Hong Kong to Cape Town beginning March 10, costing $4,627 a person and up. The final segment, leaving Cape Town April 5 for Southampton, England, starts at $2,487 a person, double, for 13 days. Information: (800) 728-6273 or www.cunard.com.

snippet: David Halberstam profiles Charles Mohr, a 'reporter's reporter,' who worked for New York Times from 1964 until his death 25 years later; notes that Mohr covered every major story in world during those years, most notably wars in Middle East and in...
lead_paragraph: NOTHING changed the nature of print journalism quite like the force of television. In the 1960's and 70's, the encyclopedic, omniscient style that had defined The Times was no longer enough. There had to be room for a subtler style of reporting, one that greatly enhanced the influence and judgment of the reporter on the ground. Reporters had to be able to go places that television's bulky cameras couldn't go, and produce stories that television, with its inherent limits of time and space, could not match.
abstract: David Halberstam profiles Charles Mohr, a 'reporter's reporter,' who worked for New York Times from 1964 until his death 25 years later; notes that Mohr covered every major story in world during those years, most notably wars in Middle East and in Vietnam; photo (L) (Special section marking New York Times' 150th birthday)

lead_paragraph: MALONEY-James D. After a short, but courageous battle against cancer, 72 year old James Maloney of Juno Beach, FL, passed away on July 30, 2001. Born to Irish immigrant parents on February 28, 1929 in Cincinnati, OH, Mr. Maloney carved out a full and meaningful life along with an illustrious career in the soft drink industry that spanned more than four decades. He began that career in 1954 when he joined the Pepsi Cola Bottling Co. as an assistant driver. Mr. Maloney steadily rose through the ranks of Pepsi Cola in Cincinnati, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, and finally New York, where he was named Vice President of National Sales. In 1986, Mr. Maloney joined the Coca Cola Bottling Co. of Ohio as President, Chief Executive Officer. After a short stint in Akron, he moved to the Big Apple where he was named President and Chief Operating Officer of The Coca Cola Bottling Co. of New York, Inc. Mr. Maloney retired in 1996 as Chairman and CEO of the company. He resided in Juno Beach with his wife of fifty years, Jean Ann Maloney. He is also survived by his children, James T. & Rita Maloney of Acworth, GA, Kathleen Tebbe & her partner of nine years, Jim Quigley of Birmingham, MI., and Kevin Maloney of Jupiter, FL. He will be sorely missed by his six grandchildren, Allison, Shannon, Jennifer, Ryan, Thomas and Daniel along with their mother, Terry Maloney. He is also survived by his loving brother, Thomas J. Maloney of Cincinnati, OH. An avid golfer, Mr. Maloney was a member of Ballen Isle Country Club. He was also a Communicant of St. Patrick's Catholic Church, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Visitation will be 9AM-11AM Saturday, August 4, at Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, 250 Center St, Jupiter, FL. Mass of the Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11:30 AM Saturday at St. Patrick's Catholic Church, 13591 Prosperity Farms Rd, Palm Beach Gardens with Rev. Bernard Dooley as celebrant. Family requests donations in Mr. Maloney's memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

lead_paragraph: Q. What is Internet 2? Is it a separate network from the original Internet?
abstract: Q. What is Internet 2? Is it a separate network from the original Internet?    A. Internet 2 is a nonprofit project  to develop more advanced networking applications and new technologies. lead_paragraph: Duke Energy Seeks Deal To End California Inquiries
abstract: Duke Energy Seeks Deal To End California Inquiries  Duke Energy, a power-generating company accused of overcharging customers millions of dollars during California's energy crisis, has secretly offered Gov. Gray Davis a deal that it hopes will solve its legal problems while helping to calm the state's electricity markets.    The proposed settlement, outlined in documents prepared by Duke's lawyers, calls for an end to state investigations, private suits and state complaints to federal authorities involving alleged overcharging by Duke. lead_paragraph: Four years almost to the day after the government first sued Microsoft for violating the terms of its antitrust settlement, the United States ended its prosecution of Microsoft with another proposed settlement. This consent decree is weaker than the one Microsoft had apparently agreed to before a United States Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed the finding of liability against the company last summer. Some may wonder how you get a better deal after being found guilty than you did before.

lead_paragraph: FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Nathalie Friedman, a cherished friend of the Jewish community and beloved sister of our former board member and longtime advocate, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein. A member of one of New York's leading Jewish families, Dr. Friedman was a brilliant scholar and remarkable person. During her career as a professor of sociology at Barnard College, she conducted meticulous research and produced prominent studies on the role of education on Jewish women, the family, and the community. We send our deepest sympathies to Dr. Friedman's husband, Israel; to her children, Steven and Sheira Schacter, Jessica and Allen Gribetz, Judy and Mark Tykocinski, and Naomi Schacter-Price and Jonathan Price; to her 18 grandchildren; to Rabbi Lookstein and his wife, Audrey; and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO
abstract: FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Nathalie Friedman, a cherished friend of the Jewish community and beloved sister of our former board member and longtime advocate, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein. A member of one of New York's leading Jewish families, Dr. Friedman was a brilliant scholar and remarkable person. During her career as a professor of sociology at Barnard College, she conducted meticulous research and produced prominent studies on the role of education on Jewish women, the family, and the community. We send our deepest sympathies to Dr. Friedman's husband, Israel; to her children, Steven and Sheira Schacter, Jessica and Allen Gribetz, Judy and Mark Tykocinski, and Naomi Schacter-Price and Jonathan Price; to her 18 grandchildren; to Rabbi Lookstein and his wife, Audrey; and to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO     FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie (nee Lookstein). The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a distinguished educator who formally served on the faculty of Stern College for Women, beloved wife of Rabbi Israel Friedman and cherished mother of Steve (and Sheira) Schacter, Jessica (and Dr. Allen) Gribetz, Judy (and Mark) Tykochinski, and Naomi (and Dr. Jonathan) Price. She was the beloved sister of Rabbi Haskel (and Audrey) Lookstein, member of the Board of Directors, Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies, and chair holder, Dr. Joseph H. Lookstein Chair of Homiletics at Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. Heartfelt condolences are extended to all the members of the Friedman/ Lookstein families. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees     FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its affiliates mourn the passing of our esteemed Life Trustee, the beloved wife of our revered member Israel Friedman, the beloved mother of our devoted members, Steven Schacter and Jessica Gribetz and of Judith Tykocinski and Naomi Schacter Price, the beloved sister of Audrey and Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, and the devoted daughter of the late Rabbi and Mrs. Joseph H. Lookstein. She gave loving service to the entire Kehilath Jeshurun family. We all join together to mourn the loss of this extraordinary Jewish woman and extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President     FRIEDMAN-Nathalie. The Board of Trustees and Administration of The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester acknowledge with profound sorrow the death of Nathalie Friedman, beloved mother of our esteemed trustee Steven Schacter, and grandmother of our alumni Erica, Elizabeth, Joanna and Margot. May her memory be a blessing to her family and may Steve, Sheira, and the entire family find solace in the comfort of friends and community. M. Mac Schwebel, Chairman Board of Trustees James Dubin, Vice Chairman Board of Trustees Elliot D. Spiegel, Headmaster     FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie. The Ramaz School family mourns tha passing of the beloved mother of our devoted Vice Chairman, Steven Schacter, and our alumnae Jessica Gribetz, Judith Tykocinski and Naomi Schacter Price, the beloved sister of Audrey and Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, and the adoring grandmother of five alumnae and three current students. We extend hearfelt condolences to all the members of the bereaved family. David N. Kahn, Chairman Board of Trustees     FRIEDMAN-Nathalie. Congregation of Young Israel of Harrison mourns the passing of Nathalie Friedman. Beloved mother of its esteemed board member, Steven Schacter. We extend heartfelt condolences to the bereaved family. Yaakov Bienenfeld, Rabbi Stephen Apple, President

snippet: Anne Raver interview with Diane Ackerman, poet and author of Cultivating Delight: A Natural History of My Garden, at her home in Cayuga Heights, NY; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IT'S a bit of a shock, at first, to see Diane Ackerman's garden. Ms. Ackerman, a poet and author of 18 books, talks plenty about squirrels and deer and hummingbird feeders in ''Cultivating Delight: A Natural History of My Garden,'' just published by HarperCollins. But she writes about them, along with her roses and her peonies, as if she were exploring the wild beauty of some just-discovered Amazon.

abstract: NOBODY wants the Minnesota Twins to survive more than the wrestler-cum-governor, but Jesse Ventura says he will not ''give'' to the chokehold of contraction. He will not beg, borrow or bully for public money to build baseball a new ballpark.    ''During the campaign in 1998, that was a specific question during the debates -- do you support public funding?'' Ventura said yesterday by telephone. ''I said I did not. My position is putting me in a rough spot, but it's not going to change.''

snippet: Anne Raver article on newly restored biblical garden at Cathedral Church of St John the Divine, New York City, where many people are seeking solace in wake of terrorist attacks; designer Keith Corlett comments, interview; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: YOU can hear the sound of water before you see it, burbling out of the fountain at the newly restored biblical garden at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The garden, tucked behind the church that towers over Amsterdam Avenue at 113th Street, offers solace to those in search of calm, a place to do some soul-searching or simply to contemplate a flower. This week, many people sought its benches and the shade of its grapevine-covered arbors.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Brown's Tavern in Locust Valley, NY (M)
lead_paragraph: BROWN'S TAVERN would be a bargain anywhere, but in a North Shore fox-and-hounds community like Locust Valley, it's a revelation. Its simple, satisfying food has generated enthusiasm in the ranks of the local, old-money country club set and young penny-wise families from afar. Both are making the trek to the Plaza, a smart, stylish shopping center filled with elegant little boutiques in the middle of town. There, at No. 4 (516-676-5793), where the Tavern on the Plaza had been, an eager-to-please Scottish family has opened a warm, cozy restaurant with prices that please, food that generates vivid tastes and people who charm.

abstract: Q. I am developing a Web site and would like to include a message board, but I have no idea how to do it. What is the best way for a novice to approach this? Do I need to have my own server?    A. Web-based message boards, also called Web bulletin boards, can be an excellent way to involve people in your site. There is plenty of software available, both commercial and free, that will let you create customized message boards.

snippet: Returning holiday gifts bought online has been made easier by e-merchants seeking new customers and repeat business; conveniences include prepaid return labels, ability to track returns status by e-mail and integration of online retailers and thei...
lead_paragraph: RETURNING gifts, like throwing out the Christmas tree, is one of those holiday hangover chores that many people try to put off as long as possible. But if the unwanted gifts were bought online, you may find the process a little more bearable this year. In their frantic quest for customers and repeat business, online retailers have taken steps to make returning items easier. Conveniences like prepaid return labels, the ability to track a return's status by e-mail and the integration of online retailers and their offline counterparts are now for the most part standard.

snippet: A O Scott article on new Iranian films that allow Americans a glimpse or complexities of Islam and Middle East today; discusses Mohsen Makhmalbaf's Kandahar, Majid Majidi's Baran, Abbas Kiarostami's ABC Africa and Jafar Panahi's The Circle; photos...
lead_paragraph: BY now, anyone who reads the newspapers is aware that Kandahar is the name of the city in southern Afghanistan that has become known as the Taliban's main stronghold. It is also the name of an extraordinary film by the Iranian director Mohsen Makhmalbaf that was shown at this year's Cannes and Toronto film festivals and which will be released in New York next month. When I saw ''Kandahar'' at Cannes in May, I was transfixed by its images and moved by its story of an exiled Afghan woman venturing back into her native country to search for her sister. The world it depicted seemed, to me and to other Westerners in attendance, far away and even -- in part because of the lyricism Mr. Makhmalbaf brings to his grimmest pictures of war and deprivation -- exotic.
abstract: A O Scott article on new Iranian films that allow Americans a glimpse or complexities of Islam and Middle East today; discusses Mohsen Makhmalbaf's Kandahar, Majid Majidi's Baran, Abbas Kiarostami's ABC Africa and Jafar Panahi's The Circle; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: SOUTHERN Suffolk's newest culinary star is also one of its oldest. The Bayport House, then called the Fiat Inn Hotel, opened in 1869. During its 132-year history, the landmark building has been a stagecoach stop, waiting room for the train, speakeasy and restaurant. The food has roamed from American to German to Italian. Today, everything is new at this historic spot: owners, chef, staff, food and ambience.
abstract: SOUTHERN Suffolk's newest culinary star is also one of its oldest. The Bayport House, then called the Fiat Inn Hotel, opened in 1869. During its 132-year history, the landmark building has been a stagecoach stop, waiting room for the train, speakeasy and restaurant. The food has roamed from American to German to Italian. Today, everything is new at this historic spot: owners, chef, staff, food and ambience.    When I last visited the Bayport House, about a decade ago, ristorante was part of its name. It served very good Northern Italian food but was equally renowned for its Christmas decorations. Garlands, wreaths, trees, boughs, lights, snowflakes and balls started appearing the day after Halloween. In a starring role was a plethora of santas, from the jolly fellow in his sleigh on the lawn to a regiment of moving santas and Mrs. Clauses within.

snippet: Jonathan Reynolds Style column on pajama food, suggesting that all-stars of pajama food are probably peanut butter, ice cream and just about any form of mashed potatoes; observes that PJ food is customarily dish that one had as a child; recipes (L...
lead_paragraph: Isn't it redundant to call anything you put in your mouth voluntarily ''comfort food''? All food is comforting, or we'd be eating nothing but Dr. Atkins Diet Advantage Bars and gravel (not that the two are indistinguishable), with possibly a few vitamins thrown in. Unless you are on some kind of nasty medical diet or undergoing a fraternity initiation, there is no such thing as ''punitive food.'' That said, the current ether does seem to demand pleasing palliatives designed for a sort of refined slothfulness.

lead_paragraph: Q. I often need to send an e-mail message to a group of people but don't want each recipient to be able to see all other recipients' names and addresses. I can't find a Bcc line in the Outlook Express window, so how can I avoid revealing the addresses?
abstract: Q. I often need to send an e-mail message to a group of people but don't want each recipient to be able to see all other recipients' names and addresses. I can't find a Bcc line in the Outlook Express window, so how can I avoid revealing the addresses?    A. Some e-mail programs handle Bcc's, or blind carbon copies, differently from other programs. (Normally the Bcc line in the header of an e-mail message program allows you to hide the names and addresses of your mail recipients. Any addresses entered in the To or Cc -- carbon copy -- lines on the message will be visible to all recipients.)

lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard, Silicon Valley's first start-up, still does not seem sure what it wants to focus on when it grows up. Last year it tried unsuccessfully to buy the consulting business of PricewaterhouseCoopers. Then yesterday H-P, the company that two Stanford engineering graduates, William Hewlett and David Packard, started in 1938 with $538 in a now fabled one-car Palo Alto garage, announced that it would spend $25 billion of its stock to acquire Compaq, the world's second-largest personal computer maker.

lead_paragraph: A HERD of horses emerged from the early morning mist of northern Texas. It seemed then that John Wayne might ride out of a red-clay wash at any moment, tip his hat to me, and mouth a laconic ''Howdy, ma'am.''

snippet: Mary Tannen surveys some new skin-care products; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Recidivism runs rampant. Smokers who quit years ago are embracing the weed with renewed fervor. Sippers of white-wine spritzers are suddenly demanding vodka martinis with olives. The well-intentioned head for yoga class and wake up hours later covered with powdered sugar in a back booth at Donut Dive. Stairmasters gather dust; chins multiply; reddened eyes peer from darkened sockets. Pimples are everywhere. ''It doesn't matter,'' we say, but one morning, in the slanting November light, the mirror catches our eyes and we realize that yes, it does matter, and something has to be done about it -- fast.
abstract: Mary Tannen surveys some new skin-care products; photo (M)

snippet: Lee Ellen Griffith, Monmouth County (NJ) Historical Assn director, answers questions about Marlpit Hall, built in 1756 and now restored; photo (On the Map column) (M)
lead_paragraph: Marlpit Hall in Middletown Township, built in 1756, is an unusually long house that opens onto a side yard rather than onto Kings Highway. The Taylor family owned the property until the mid-1930's when a Monmouth County woman, Margaret Haskell, purchased and restored the property for the Monmouth County Historical Association. The association has spent the past eight years making structural repairs and restoring the interior to the way it looked when it was first built. The house reopened to the public last month and a grand opening celebration is scheduled for Sept. 16. The house is open on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays from 1 to 4 p.m. and on Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Lee Ellen Griffith, director of the Monmouth County Historical Association, talked recently about the house.

snippet: Mark Bittman reviews several restaurants in San Francisco's Mission District: Andalu, Alma, Slanted Door, Foreign Cinema and Luna Park; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: I KNOW of no other North American neighborhood where you can have as much fun and eat in as many different, affordable restaurants as you can in the Mission District of San Francisco. The dot-com boom bought tons of new money here, and two years ago, when pioneering yuppies had gentrified the Mission -- or ruined it, depending on your perspective -- I began visiting regularly. There were a few restaurants I already knew: the venerable Taquería, the 10-year-old crêperie called Ti Couz, and the newer Universal Cafe (actually in nearby Potrero Hill), Delfina, and the Slanted Door.

lead_paragraph: JAKUBOVITZ-Jerome R. The Board of Directors of Stern College for Women is deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member, Jerome Jakubovitz. Jerry was a very special man and we shall sorely miss his wisdom, his business acumen, his commitment to Judaism and education, and his generosity of both heart and spirit. To his beloved family, children and grandchildren, we extend our sincerest sympathy, and to his beautiful wife Joan we send collectively a great, big hug. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marjorie Blenden SCW Chairman of the Board E. I live in SoHo, the repair shop is down three flight of stairs and many blocks away. How was I going to get the computer to the shop? I pulled out my stock of rolling suitcases -- too small. Construction dolly -- how could I pad and wrap it for a bumpy journey? Then I spied my neighbor's stroller parked downstairs, festooned with neon AstroTurf and bobbing plastic daisies.

snippet: This pastry chef makes house calls. Michel Floranc, above, who owns Toute Sweet, a wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake soufflés or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party, or he will be there simply to put his...
lead_paragraph: This pastry chef makes house calls. Michel Floranc, above, who owns Toute Sweet, a wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake soufflés or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party, or he will be there simply to put his desserts on plates with his own personal touch. In his repertory are excellent thin-crusted apple galettes seasoned with a whiff of cinnamon and decorated with a tangle of dried apple peel (left); sumptuous little chestnut cakes; classics like éclairs; and cakes for special occasions. Desserts prepared and put on plates in your home start at $8 a portion (no minimum number of guests), plus a charge of $25 an hour for the chef. Without Mr. Floranc's participation, the pastries start at $1.50 each for miniature tartlets and éclairs. Apple galettes are $7 each, and most large tarts and cakes, which serve 6 to 12, are $25 to $45. Delivery is available in Manhattan for orders of at least $40; (718) 429-8714.

abstract: Hewlett Warns on Profit And Plans to Cut Some Jobs  Hewlett-Packard warned that its quarterly earnings would fall short of Wall Street's estimates by at least 50 percent. It said it would eliminate as much as 20 percent of its managerial staff and take a charge of $150 million.    But the company offered a glimmer of hope for an improved second half of the year, saying the sharp declines in consumer sales of its products in the United States have slowed and do not appear to be worsening. lead_paragraph: As you drive west on Prospect Plains Road in Monroe Township, if you don't see the left just before the railroad tracks, you'll miss Cranberry's Gourmet Shoppe. Fortunately for its co-owners, Tom Scaramuzzo and Sam Ippolito, as many as 250 people a day manage to make the turn. The shop's out-of-the-way setting would be ideal for a country store or a rural post office, both of which the place once was. As you enter, there is a counter case filled with home-baked goods. In the rear is another counter with a variety of salads and more. In the middle, surrounded by remnants of the past -- including, on the wall, the storefront window from the onetime ''General Store,'' plus a ''Joshua Carter & Sons'' sign, with the likeness of a pig -- are a half-dozen tables. More tables are one flight up and on a back patio. Mr. Scaramuzzo, who used to work in research and development at General Foods, describes the menu items as ''country-style'' and, above all, ''made from scratch.'' Among items, $4.25 and up, are smoked chicken breast with apples, grapes and walnuts on a bed of lettuce; a grilled veggie sandwich; and tortellini salad with spicy andouille sausage, sweet peppers and red onions tossed in a basil shallot. And then there is the dish on which Ames Hoyt, an environmental manager from Carter-Wallace Inc., 15 minutes away in Princeton, was recently feasting: caramelized onions and peas. Just right -- a little gourmet, and a lot country. Norm Oshrin

More tables are one flight up and on a back patio. Among items, $4.25 and up, are smoked chicken breast with apples, grapes and walnuts on a bed of lettuce; a grilled veggie sandwich; and tortellini salad with spicy andouille sausage, sweet peppers and red onions tossed in a basil shallot. And then there is the dish on which Ames Hoyt, an environmental manager from Carter-Wallace Inc., 15 minutes away in Princeton, was recently feasting: caramelized onions and peas. Just right -- a little gourmet, and a lot country.   Norm Oshrin    Cranberry's Gourmet Shoppe, 8 Public Road, Monroe; (609) 655-0134; open weekdays, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. and Saturdays, 8 a.m. to 3 p.m.

lead_paragraph: AS the car crossed the Ponquoque Bridge and headed east on Dune Road in Hampton Bays, someone in the back seat said, ''Are you sure there's something open down there?'' It was late November and the road ahead was dark and desolate, not a person, car or light in sight. Then, near land's end, just 45 seconds from the Shinnecock Inlet, there were lights, people, action and that rarest of Long Island restaurant birds, a good, low-priced seafood spot. For despite nearly a thousand miles of coastline, Long Island has very few good fish houses, especially modestly priced ones.
abstract: AS the car crossed the Ponquoque Bridge and headed east on Dune Road in Hampton Bays, someone in the back seat said, ''Are you sure there's something open down there?'' It was late November and the road ahead was dark and desolate, not a person, car or light in sight. Then, near land's end, just 45 seconds from the Shinnecock Inlet, there were lights, people, action and that rarest of Long Island restaurant birds, a good, low-priced seafood spot. For despite nearly a thousand miles of coastline, Long Island has very few good fish houses, especially modestly priced ones.    Sunwater's Grill in Soleau's Wharf and Marina, at 369 Dune Road (631-728-1722), is just that, an all-American waterfront seafood restaurant.

lead_paragraph: EVERY restaurant wants to have a personality. Unfortunately, many of them start from the outside and work in. They concentrate on getting the look and the atmosphere down. Much attention is devoted to the soundtrack. The food is not so much created as curated. It's treated as style. From this frantic activity, like the earth emerging from a cloud of swirling hot gas, something resembling character is supposed to rise. It never does.

lead_paragraph: HARMON-Howard, D.V.M. Age 77, died March 19, 2001, in Escondido, CA. Born in New Castle, PA, he grew up in New York City. After graduating from Pennsylvania State University in 1942, he received his veterinary degree (D.V.M.) from Cornell in 1945. Dr. Harmon owned and operated a successful veterinary practice in Rye, N.Y., for almost 35 years, and was a member of local, state, and national veterinary associations. Since his retirement in 1985, Dr. Harmon lived in Escondido, California, and was intimately involved in the conception, staffing, and organization of the Veterinary Specialty Referral Hospital of San Diego, located at the Helen Woodward Animal Center in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. He served for many years as a member of the Board of Directors of the Center. He is survived by Harriet, his beloved wife; his children, Kim and Robert; his daughter-in-law, Susan, and his grandson, Max, who was the apple of his eye. He loved his many dear friends and touched more people than he knew. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Helen Woodward Animal Center, POB 64, Rancho Santa Fe, CA 92067.

lead_paragraph: SO there you are, standing dazed in Aisle 51 of CompUniverse or Soup-Up City, shopping for a computer for your off-to-college son or daughter. Aisles of beige boxes stretch as far as the eye can see. The sales clerks aren't even old enough to drive, let alone coherently explain the differences between the 900MHzAMD/128MB/ 10G unit for $799 and the 1GP3/256MB/ 20GB for $999. Maybe you should just give your Visa card to your kid and forget the whole thing.

lead_paragraph: WHAT to say about a restaurant run by a terrifically creative chef, Brian MacMenamin, who surrounds seafood with interesting, varied and delicious garnishes, where fish is pristine, but often overcooked, and where service can be inattentive and agonizingly slow? Considerations like these make assigning a rating to Larchmont Avenue Oyster House a complicated business.
abstract: WHAT to say about a restaurant run by a terrifically creative chef, Brian MacMenamin, who surrounds seafood with interesting, varied and delicious garnishes, where fish is pristine, but often overcooked, and where service can be inattentive and agonizingly slow? Considerations like these make assigning a rating to Larchmont Avenue Oyster House a complicated business.     A few specials written neatly on a ribbon of blackboard bordering the dining area include oysters of the day. Roasted on the shell, six Wellfleets with smooth, sweet Champagne beurre blanc and snippets of leek circled a center of greens crowned with frizzled leek tops, a lovely starter. Or begin with a plate of cool Nantuckets, Belons, Wellfleets and Scookums on the half shell -- light and elegant. The assortment, however, arrived unaccountably mixed on the plate, and so were unidentifiable. Trying to help, a server explained that some were larger and some smaller. To turn over a shell for further identification would have meant losing the rare saline liquid of the oysters. But only fried oysters were disappointing: they were supple enough but a heavy batter left them looking crude and tortured.

abstract: For Artists Starting Out  TOMORROW -- Young people in theater, dance and film will be supported by a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria that will raise money for the Princess Grace Foundation. It provides grants to promising young artists, and this year, half of the proceeds from the gala will be donated to children of those killed in the Sept. 11 attacks. The black-tie evening begins at 7 with cocktails, with dinner at 8 and dancing to the music of the Starlight Orchestra. Tickets, $600, from (212) 317-1470.    Balanchine's Work  TUESDAY -- Balanchine's ''Symphony in C'' will be among the works performed in the opening of the American Ballet Theater's fall season, at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. The evening, to help the company's performances and educational programs, begins at 7 with the performance. Dinner will follow at the University Club, 1 West 54th Street, at 9:30. Tickets, $600, from (212) 477-3030 ext. 3239.

lead_paragraph: For those who have been overlooked, slighted or perhaps even fired by an uncaring employer, an opportunity for revenge may be at hand.
abstract: For those who have been overlooked, slighted or perhaps even fired by an uncaring employer, an opportunity for revenge may be at hand.    Beginning today, a group of software companies, the Business Software Alliance, is appealing to disgruntled employees in New York and four other cities to act as informers if their companies are using unlicensed copies of computer software. A study commissioned by the alliance, which began conducting such campaigns in other cities in August, estimates that American software companies lost more than $2.6 billion to piracy last year.

abstract: Federal appeals court unanimously throws out lower court's order that Microsoft Corp should be broken up, although it does find that company repeatedly abused its monopoly power in software business; appeals court sharply chastises District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who oversaw Microsoft antitrust trial, and removes him from any further involvement in case because of derogatory comments he made to press about company and its senior executives; opinion is welcomed by Microsoft, but it is also hailed by federal and state officials for affirming principle that Microsoft bullied smaller software rivals, computer makers and other large companies like chip maker Intel, and broke law in ways that stifled competition; Justice Dept officials, some state attorneys general, and Microsoft executives say they have not decided what to do next; they have three options: they can appeal to Supreme Court, proceed to new trial before different district judge, or reopen settlement negotiations; chronology of case; chart of issues and findings; photo (L)

snippet: Michael Kimmelman Year in Review column on New York art scene, particularly in wake of terrorist attacks; praises New York's indomitable spirit as proof that life goes on; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: BAD news first. Layoffs and cutbacks at the Guggenheim were reported just before Thanksgiving, then at the Whitney a week later. The Metropolitan is coping with an enormous deficit. Almost every museum is in trouble to some degree. Exhibitions have been canceled or delayed (an Eva Hesse retrospective won't be coming from San Francisco to the Whitney next year; a Douglas Gordon show won't make it from Los Angeles to the Guggenheim). The last-quarter collapse in attendance because of fewer tourists forced many museums, including ones outside New York and Washington, to tighten belts and trim programs. At the same time, prudence caused nearly every public institution to divert at least a little more money to security.

snippet: Karla Cook reviews Les Copains restaurant in Princeton, NJ; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN a bite of my friend's dinner is still on my mind days later, I you know it's a meal worth having for myself. As restaurant dinners go, it was fairly simple: Frenched pork loin, slightly salty, grilled and resting on a bed of black-eyed peas with bacon and sprinkled with fresh tarragon. It was a compelling combination, one that made my friend reminisce about tarragon and its part in wooing his wife. The entree needed only a little less cooking and some sautéed greens or maybe grilled apples to replace a Dali-style drape of a goat-cheese crepe, and it would have been a meal suitable for reminiscing, too.

Funeral service Friday, July 13th, 11 AM at The Riverside Chapel, 76th Street & Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights, 333 7th Ave, 13th Floor, New York, New York 10001-5004.    FISCHMAN-Bernard D. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of our esteemed member, the beloved husband of our devoted member Hilda Fischman. We extend our condolences to the entire bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President    FISCHMAN-Bernard D. The Child Development Center of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services is deeply saddened by the passing of Bernard Fischman, former Divisional Committee member of the Child Development Center and beloved husband of longtime CDC clinician, Hilda Fischman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Hilda, his children, Bob and Judy, son-inlaw, Harmon, and grandchildren. Renee J. Ward, Chair, CDC Divisional Committee Alice Kross Frankel, M.D., Director Emerita, CDC Marian Davidson-Amodeo, C.S.W., Director, CDC    FISCHMAN - Bernard D. We mourn the passing of our friend and counselor, Bernie Fischman. For many years, all of us, and our departed founder Stanley Stahl, benefitted from his friendship and wise judgement in good times and in difficult times. His wide-ranging scholarship and dedication to the right and to the true were unsurpassed. We will miss him greatly. Our sympathies to his loving family. Richard F. Czaja, Gregg S. Wolpert, Marianne Dziuba, David B. Manowitz Stahl Real Estate Co.    FISCHMAN-Bernard D. A kind and strong man of uncommon integrity; his life was a Blessing. His wise counsel and personal encouragement aided Media Judaica for three decades. His legacy of love of family and of ethical concern for countless others will surely endure. Rabbi Jonathan D. Levine, and The Directors of Media Judaica    FISCHMAN-Bernard. The Directors, Officers and staff of the Apple Bank for Savings mourn the passing of Bernard Fischman, long-term Director of the Bank, a man of great wisdom and kindness, who achieved distinction in his profession and was a friend to us all. We extend our profound condolences to his family.    FISCHMAN-Bernard. We shall miss our beloved Bernie, who has been such a friend and inspiration to us all. Our deepest condolences to his family. Donald Jonas, Chairman of the Board, and all Board of Directors of Lechters, Inc.    FISCHMAN-Bernard D. Few have loved mercy, pursued justice, and walked humbly with God, as did he with his beloved wife Hilda. The Rackman Family

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Dutch restaurant NL in Greenwich Village; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The city founded by the Dutch finally has a Dutch restaurant. It's NL, for the Netherlands, and it starts with a tremendous advantage: virtually no one has the slightest idea what Dutch cuisine is. In a bleak essay on the food of the Netherlands, the Oxford Companion to Food singles out stamppot (mashed potatoes and vegetables) and pap as the country's two crowning glories. Cheese, pancakes and beer are probably the only culinary contributions that have made any international impression.

abstract: Black bears facing apparent food shortage in mountains of New Mexico are foraging through refrigerators, digging through trash bins and picking fruit from backyard trees in search of good meal; black bear sightings are fairly routine in mountainous states like New Mexico, but residents are increasingly anxious as record number of encounters, some violent, are being reported; incident that most aroused public anxiety is recent mauling death of 93-year-old woman in her home; black bears are not considered predators, but now there are reports of bears breaking into homes; photos (M)

snippet: Photo of bicoastal hipsters at party at Les Deux Cafe in Los Angeles (Pulse column) (S)
lead_paragraph: It could have been an episode of ''Oprah'' where long-lost friends are joyfully reunited, but instead it was Cachet, the Monday-night party at Les Deux Café in Hollywood that's a must stop for bicoastal hipsters seeking their own kind. Last week, revelers in Gucci hats and Frankie B. hip-huggers embraced each other with exuberant greetings like: ''How long have you been living out here, girl?'' and ''I'm staying at the Standard, too!'' Donovan Leitch and his wife, Kirsty Hume, the model, who are based in Woodstock, N.Y., sipped cocktails on the patio with Sofia Coppola and Vincent Gallo, the actor and part-time NoLIta resident.

lead_paragraph: I HAVE used the Macintosh operating system for more than a decade, and Windows off and on since it became less annoying a few years ago, but the notion of trying Linux intrigued me. Could someone like me, without a computer science degree or past love affairs with a Radio Shack TRS-80, do anything with Linux -- like installing it on an old PC and getting it to do things I usually do on my I.B.M. ThinkPad or Mac G4 desktop-tower machine?

lead_paragraph: IMAGINE our surprise when we arrived for lunch at Wildfire in Greenwich only to find that the restaurant was gone. But, presto, in its place was the Barcelona Restaurant & Wine Bar, a new branch of a restaurant by the same name in South Norwalk.
abstract: IMAGINE our surprise when we arrived for lunch at Wildfire in Greenwich only to find that the restaurant was gone. But, presto, in its place was the Barcelona Restaurant & Wine Bar, a new branch of a restaurant by the same name in South Norwalk.    The decor at Barcelona is similar to the short-lived (less than a year) Wildfire. That is no surprise. The ownership is partly the same, as are the walnut tables and chairs with woven backs and seats. The colorful area rugs and wall paintings, however, are new.

lead_paragraph: NEVER before has Paris seen such a vast choice of tastes, flavors, cuisines and styles of dining as it enjoys today. From the new and tiny Astrance (just room for 28 diners) to the trendy and enticing Korova (where, hard as it may be to believe, you can enjoy chicken cooked in a Coca-Cola sauce) and on to the talk-of-the-town all-vegetable menu at Arpege, one can find just about everything one might desire, at any hour of the day.

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of D'Artagnan Restaurant and Rotisserie on East 46th Street; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Some restaurants hire consultants and big-name designers to create a personality. Others simply have one. D'Artagnan Restaurant and Rotisserie not only has personality, it has character. It is odd, even a little goofy, and utterly sincere in its devotion to the products and the cooking of one of France's least-known, least-touristed regions, Gascony. As the restaurant's name suggests, it is the home of a fiery hero in ''The Three Musketeers,'' and, more important to diners, a region devoted to foie gras, armagnac, ducks, prunes and unabashed calorie consumption.

''It's got everything you expect from a Williams play,'' she said. ''A faded belle (in this case a man), a brutish animal type who is irresistible to women, a bigger-than-life heroine in a tough spot, and a rocking chair in the moonlight.''

snippet: Michael Pollan essay on arrival of spring gardening season, observing that sooner or later, most gardeners begin to look at things from perspective of their plants; comments on partnership between himself and potatoes that he plants (M)
lead_paragraph: For a while there, it looked as if this might be the year it never happened, but the gardening season has arrived at last. Last week the peas went in, finally, and today I'll plant potatoes. Nights are still way too cold to put out the tender vegetables -- tomatoes and the like -- but on my windowsills their seedlings are already pressing against the pane, leaning into the strengthening sun and the traffic of bees building outside. Am I the only gardener who, especially at this time of year, identifies with these bees? I doubt it. Sooner or later, most gardeners begin to look at things from the perspective of their plants -- and from a plant's point of view, there's really not a whole lot of difference between a human being and a bumblebee.

lead_paragraph: Q. Why are some letters in Windows dialogue boxes underlined? I assume this is significant.
abstract: Q. Why are some letters in Windows dialogue boxes underlined? I assume this is significant.    A. Those underlined letters you see on certain dialogue box buttons are hints to the shortcuts you can perform on the keyboard instead of using a mouse to select the option you want. In most cases, you can press the Alt key plus the underlined letter to perform that dialogue box action. For example, if you see the B in Browse underlined in a dialogue box button, you can press Alt and B to open the Browse window to look at files on your hard drive.

lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:    One reason many dyed-in-the-wool New Yorkers love living in the city so much is that not a day goes by without an encounter with something or someone surprising.    Earlier this year, I was heading home on Carmine Street in Greenwich Village when I saw an unfamiliar woman who seemed to be heading straight toward me. She looked to be in her mid-30's and a cut above the typical bag lady. It  quickly became clear that she wanted something from me and as she came closer, I held up my hand, palm out, and shook my head as if to say ''Sorry, but I have nothing to give you.''

snippet: An article yesterday about a decision by Timothy McVeigh to end appeals of his death sentence for the bombing of the federal building in Oklahoma City referred erroneously to the reaction of Tina Tomlin, whose husband was among those killed. The c...
lead_paragraph: An article yesterday about a decision by Timothy McVeigh to end appeals of his death sentence for the bombing of the federal building in Oklahoma City referred erroneously to the reaction of Tina Tomlin, whose husband was among those killed. The comment — "By seeming to accept his own death, he may be trying to cheat his victims out of some level of satisfaction they would have had if he had been led down the corridor to his execution still wanting to live" — was a paraphrase of Ms. Tomlin's views and should not have appeared in quotation marks.

lead_paragraph: Bon Jovi's unsurprisingly triumphant appearance Friday night at Giants Stadium was the best Fourth of July celebration ever to take place almost in August. Under a hazy half moon and a blanket of artificial stars, New Jersey's most all-American band gave the cheering crowd plenty of corn and apple pie along with the fireworks obligatory at every arena rock show.
abstract: Bon Jovi's unsurprisingly triumphant appearance Friday night at Giants Stadium was the best Fourth of July celebration ever to take place almost in August. Under a hazy half moon and a blanket of artificial stars, New Jersey's most all-American band gave the cheering crowd plenty of corn and apple pie along with the fireworks obligatory at every arena rock show.     This was music from a town called Hope, or New Hope at least, which is almost in New Jersey, given Bon Jovi's allegiance to the heartland within dreaming distance of the Empire State Building, a model of which formed the centerpiece of its stage set. In a two-hour show paced as energetically as a one-minute car commercial, Jon Bon Jovi led his band of loyal ruffians through endless testaments to keeping the faith, refusing to surrender, sacrificing for love, speaking the truth and getting wild, but not so wild that any of the aforementioned virtuous stances would be compromised.

headline.main: Bon Jovi Keeps That July Fourth Spirit Rolling
headline.print_headline: ROCK REVIEW; Bon Jovi Keeps That July Fourth Spirit Rolling

snippet: William Grimes reviews Artisanal, restaurant at Park Ave and 32nd St; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ARTISANAL is a brasserie with a lot of cheese. That doesn't sound especially enticing. So let me put it another way. Artisanal is a big, very good-looking brasserie with more varieties of cheese than most human beings will encounter in a lifetime. Its cheese menu amounts almost to a dare: do you love cheese enough, and do you have the patience, to work your way through nearly 200 cheeses, from cabécou de Rocamadour to the unpronounceable Garrotxa to Sardinia's pride, callu de cabreddu (described on the menu as ''challenging, soft, mouth-numbing'')?

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    ELECTRIC LIGHT, by Seamus Heaney. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) Heaney's new book of poems is a compendium of genres set in an array of forms and tuned to many kinds of experience, the work of a mature poet and world citizen, aware of his cultural authority as a public man and of the rights and responsibilities that go with it.    DOUBLE FOLD: Libraries and the Assault on Paper, by Nicholson Baker. (Random House, $25.95.) A jeremiad, a philippic, an imprecation against library professionals and all their friends who are bent on discarding books and newspapers made of genuine righteous paper while recording their contents on vile, accursed microfilm.    AFTERIMAGE, by Helen Humphreys. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) A Canadian writer's lyrical, alluring novel, a kind of gloss on the life of the Victorian photographer Julia Margaret Cameron; the character at its heart, however, is a passionately self-educated housemaid from starving Ireland who serves as a model and as the prize in a family tug of war.    GRANT, by Jean Edward Smith. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) The author, a political scientist at Marshall University, takes issue with the conventional wisdom that Grant's presidency was an embarrassment to the nation, a judgment he attributes to the work of intellectual snobs like Henry Adams and of scholars who favored white supremacy.    AN UNEXPECTED LIGHT: Travels in Afghanistan, by Jason Elliot. (Picador USA, $30.) The author explores past and present, at considerable personal risk, in the Afghan resistance to Russia and in the collapse that preceded the Taliban rule of the present.    FACING THE WIND: A True Story of Tragedy and Reconciliation, by Julie Salamon. (Random House, $24.95.) A breathtaking account of a man who killed his wife and children and was found insane, but soon released from custody -- and of what happened after that, by a television critic for The Times.    HONEYMOON: And Other Stories, by Kevin Canty. (Nan A. Talese/ Doubleday, $21.) Elliptical, impressionistic short stories, in a style at once tender and telegraphic, featuring characters who do the wrong things for the wrong reasons; for starters, in the first story Godzilla declares his love for Tokyo.    REMEMBER ME TO HARLEM: The Letters of Langston Hughes and Carl Van Vechten, 1925-1964, edited by Emily Bernard. (Knopf, $30.) The record of an ironic, ribald, frequently poignant interracial friendship between a poet who interpreted the black experience and a novelist who did his best to promote Hughes and the Harlem Renaissance.    THREE APPLES FELL FROM HEAVEN, by Micheline Aharonian Marcom. (Riverhead, $23.95.) A vivid first novel placed in the Turkish massacres of Armenians during World War I; one character, an American consul, wonders, as the reader is meant to do, why such cruelties are so little noted by the world.

lead_paragraph: FOR years, my attitude toward California sauvignon blanc was, ''Why bother?'' After all, it's hard to beat Sancerre and Pouilly-Fumé for sauvignon blanc in its purest form: crisp, piquant and herbal. New Zealand has put its brand on a bolder style of great intensity. And let's not forget the weighty, complex Bordeaux whites, which generally are blends of sauvignon blanc and sémillon.

Eating wasn't much fun because the food had to clear the several hurdles of swallowing upward, which led to frequent choking.

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    COMFORT ME WITH APPLES: More Adventures at the Table, by Ruth Reichl. (Random House, $24.95.) This second volume of memoir by The Times's former restaurant critic invokes themes larger than mere food: commune life in Berkeley, the social texture of dining out, the longing for a child.    DOUBLE FOLD: Libraries and the Assault on Paper, by Nicholson Baker. (Random House, $25.95.) A jeremiad, a philippic, an imprecation against library professionals and all their friends who are bent on discarding books and newspapers made of genuine righteous paper while recording their contents on vile, accursed microfilm.    THE GARDENS OF KYOTO, by Kate Walbert. (Scribner, $24.) An elusive, eloquent first novel whose plot moves back and forth in America, Paris and Japan as its narrator, a woman coming of age in the 1950's, construes the past in a way that obscures some uncomfortable facts but never involves her in emotional dishonesty.    AFTERIMAGE, by Helen Humphreys. (Metropolitan/Holt, $23.) A Canadian writer's lyrical, alluring novel, a kind of gloss on the life of the Victorian photographer Julia Margaret Cameron; the character at its heart, however, is a passionately self-educated housemaid from starving Ireland who serves as a model and as the prize in a family tug of war.    THE LAST REPORT ON THE MIRACLES AT LITTLE NO HORSE, by Louise Erdrich. (HarperCollins, $26.) A beguiling novel that takes place in Ojibwa country in North Dakota and centers on the innocence of Father Damien Modeste, a wilderness priest who lives for a century and is really a woman.    AN UNEXPECTED LIGHT: Travels in Afghanistan, by Jason Elliot. (Picador USA, $30.) The author explores past and present, at considerable personal risk, in the Afghan resistance to Russia and in the collapse that preceded the Taliban rule of the present.    THE MONEY AND THE POWER: The Making of Las Vegas and Its Hold on America, 1947-2000, by Sally Denton and Roger Morris. (Knopf, $26.95.) Las Vegas arraigned for drug trafficking, money laundering and politician corrupting, with quite a lot of evidence but little sense of why people have fun there.    ELECTRIC LIGHT, by Seamus Heaney. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) Heaney's new book of poems is a compendium of genres set in an array of forms and tuned to many kinds of experience, the work of a mature poet and world citizen, aware of his cultural authority as a public man and of the rights and responsibilities that go with it.    FACING THE WIND: A True Story of Tragedy and Reconciliation, by Julie Salamon. (Random House, $24.95.) A breathtaking account of a man who killed his wife and children and was found insane, but soon released from custody -- and of what happened after that, by a television critic for The Times.

lead_paragraph: I FINISHED Gary Paul Nabhan's new book, ''Coming Home to Eat: The Pleasures and Politics of Local Foods,'' at the kitchen table in between making Thanksgiving dinner: basting the pork roast (no turkey this year), chopping parsley (fresh from the garden), baking apples (local Winesaps doused with homemade maple syrup), stirring the risotto, getting out the cheese and wine from France, England and Australia.
abstract: I FINISHED Gary Paul Nabhan's new book, ''Coming Home to Eat: The Pleasures and Politics of Local Foods,'' at the kitchen table in between making Thanksgiving dinner: basting the pork roast (no turkey this year), chopping parsley (fresh from the garden), baking apples (local Winesaps doused with homemade maple syrup), stirring the risotto, getting out the cheese and wine from France, England and Australia.     Our international dinner had a few local foods, but I hadn't asked the butcher where the pig for my pork roast was raised, and I had chosen Italian rice over my home-grown heirloom potatoes. My friends arrived with dishes from their garden, though: tangy arugula to mix with my store-bought lettuce, and curried lentils simmered with okra that had ripened only a month ago on six-foot stalks.

snippet: Top chefs flaunt their fancy state-of-the- art French ovens and stoves, but in their hearts many long for a simpler time, when cooking and baking meant brick ovens and not an inch of stainless steel. That could explain the number of celebrity chef...
lead_paragraph: Top chefs flaunt their fancy state-of-the- art French ovens and stoves, but in their hearts many long for a simpler time, when cooking and baking meant brick ovens and not an inch of stainless steel. That could explain the number of celebrity chefs who have visited Peasant, a year-old restaurant in a former garage at 194 Elizabeth Street (Spring Street) on the edge of Little Italy. There, Frank DeCarlo, the chef and a co-owner, has installed a handmade brick oven, grill, rotisserie and cooktop with tandoor-like wells, all of which use wood and charcoal as fuel.

lead_paragraph: For nearly 14 years, Aggie Markowitz dispensed cheap food and free opinions from the brightly lighted restaurant at Houston and Macdougal Streets that bore her name. abstract: For nearly 14 years, Aggie Markowitz dispensed cheap food and free opinions from the brightly lighted restaurant at Houston and Macdougal Streets that bore her name. Yet despite lines every weekend for what she called ''the most perfect plate of eggs in the neighborhood,'' Ms. Markowitz finally decided that she could not meet expenses without a full bar.    So on March 5, she sold Aggie's, leaving neighbors to wonder what had befallen this unpretentious place and the two cats who patrolled it.

lead_paragraph: Their only fear was that perhaps, in all the mourning, they were making a saint of Jimmy Fox. A saint he was not. But just saying what he was -- a 42-year-old man without a home who, before he died last month, lived on the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Third Avenue -- left too much out. So the motley group that gathered down the block at the Church of the Covenant on April 3 to remember him in death talked about him.
abstract: Their only fear was that perhaps, in all the mourning, they were making a saint of Jimmy Fox. A saint he was not. But just saying what he was -- a 42-year-old man without a home who, before he died last month, lived on the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Third Avenue -- left too much out. So the motley group that gathered down the block at the Church of the Covenant on April 3 to remember him in death talked about him.     There was Lee Nagagrian in the powder-white bun and fur-trimmed poncho, who met James Ellis Fox when he was in his teens, all apple-cheeked and wide-eyed. Mr. Fox was an Athabaskan Indian born in Fort Yukon, Alaska, and reared in South Carolina, and he came to her Bleecker Street apartment one day as a handyman. He also loved to sew, she said, and made dresses for her. Soon after, when he and a New Yorker named Larry Greathouse vowed to spend their life together, they did so in her garden and then headed back to the streets.

snippet: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column explains why Ireland, whose economy has been tranformed with help of aid from European Union, has rejected EU's Nice treaty, which lays foundation for expanding EU to Eastern European countries; says Irish appreciate...
lead_paragraph: So I'm checking out of my hotel Wednesday morning, the Dromoland Castle, a real stone castle in western Ireland. The checkout desk is framed by two mannequins in suits of armor once worn by castle guards. I ask for my bill. The desk clerk sheepishly says in a thick Irish brogue that he can't give it to me now because the hotel's entire computer system crashed at 3 a.m., probably a victim of the ''Code Red'' global computer virus. I think to myself: I'm in a castle in the Irish countryside, the Irish desk clerk is surrounded by two knights in shining armor, and he's telling me in his lovely accent that a computer worm ate my bill.
abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column explains why Ireland, whose economy has been tranformed with help of aid from European Union, has rejected EU's Nice treaty, which lays foundation for expanding EU to Eastern European countries; says Irish appreciate increased economic opportunity in their country, but they fear Ireland's unique landscape and delightfully eccentric culture and identity could get paved over; says Irish, biggest beneficiaries of globalization, are becoming more aware of price they are paying (M)

lead_paragraph: OZNOT'S DISH
abstract: OZNOT'S DISH  (718) 599-6596; 79 Berry Street (Ninth Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; $$; $25 and Under: 9/2/94.      Jason Munger, the chef, has several surprises for Easter brunch at this Williamsburg spot decorated with mosaics and mismatched furniture. The blueberry pancakes are organic buckwheat, with fresh peach and pecan topping, plum ginger chutney, cinnamon and yogurt. ''Green eggs and lamb'' is two eggs over easy on a spicy lamb hash with green charmoula, a Morocan marinade,  and roasted potatoes, with salad and toast. Other choices are eggs Barbarosa: poached eggs over a crayfish and chorizo stew on a bed of arugula, served with grilled baguette and potatoes; and salmon-wrapped poached eggs over grilled brioche, with avocado and arugula. Each entree is $10 and is served with a special Greek Easter breadbasket.

snippet: Article describes 75th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, which is transformed by patiotic pomp and recast as affirmation of New York's resilience in face of tragedy of World Trade Center disaster; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: There were the usual swarms of clowns, the high-kicking cheerleaders and the puffed-up cartoon characters sailing through canyons of steel and glass. But for all its relentless levity and unapologetic commercialism, yesterday's 75th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade was partly transformed by patriotic pomp and recast as a raucous affirmation of New York's resilience in the face of tragedy.

snippet: William Grimes reviews The Harrison, restaurant in lower Manhattan; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: EVERY once in a while, a restaurant comes along that matches, in style and cuisine, the mood of the moment. The Harrison is one of those. Jimmy Bradley, the executive chef and one of the Harrison's partners, built a loyal following at his first restaurant, the Red Cat, with imaginative, modestly priced new American food. Diners love the place, and they flock to it. The temptation must have been strong to simply create Red Cat, the sequel, but Mr. Bradley resisted the urge. Instead, while sticking with a clean, all-American look for the interior, he developed a modestly priced menu poised carefully between new American and fusion cooking.
abstract: William Grimes reviews The Harrison, restaurant in lower Manhattan; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: LOWER MANHATTAN
abstract: LOWER MANHATTAN  The Mighty Hudson, In Words and Images      Douglas Lazarus traveled the length of the Hudson River by boat and painted 68 watercolors of the scenes he saw, towns and villages of the Hudson Valley, and vignettes of New York City and its harbor. Mr. Lazarus compiled his images into a book, ''Hudson River Journey: An Artist's Perspective,'' with text by Alan McKibben. The book was inspired by ''Panorama of the Hudson,'' which the artist and writer  William Wade had originally published in 1846 as a 12-foot scroll that documented the length of the river.

lead_paragraph: IN an area greatly underserved by casual restaurants, a charming one called 121 (on the road from which it takes its name) fulfills a local need; this one restaurant serves all. Its large handsome bar area invites informal gatherings, which, in mild weather, spill out onto a homey porch. In the adjoining table-packed dining room, windows that partially wrap the room reflect the sparkle of flickering votive candles.

lead_paragraph: ARTHUR'S DOWNTOWN is the third high-end restaurant to take root in the fertile soil around the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. And though it opened only last December, it feels as if it had been around forever -- or at least since the days when the words ''downtown Newark'' and ''restaurant'' didn't sound like a contradiction.
abstract: ARTHUR'S DOWNTOWN is the third high-end restaurant to take root in the fertile soil around the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. And though it opened only last December, it feels as if it had been around forever -- or at least since the days when the words ''downtown Newark'' and ''restaurant'' didn't sound like a contradiction.    It inhabits the ground floor of the Military Park Building, a fine old neo-Gothic pile that at 23 stories was New Jersey's tallest structure (unless you count the Statue of Liberty) when it went up in 1926. As Newark's downtown swiftly emptied in the 70's and 80's, so did the building, and from 1985, the ground floor languished as a plywood-boarded ruin.

lead_paragraph: FULL disclosure: This Hudson River village, 10 minutes north of Bergen County, is where I grew up in the 1950's and 60's. In my day, though Nyack had its charms, fine dining was not among them. It was a stolid workingman's town, home to shoe factories and meat markets and secondhand stores. Aside from taverns and luncheonettes, I remember only one restaurant -- a Chinese place whose egg rolls could have served as ballast down at Julius Petersen's Boat Yard.

snippet: Joanne Starkey reviews Dave's Grill in Montauk, Long Island (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN East End diners tire of the latest see-and-be-seen restaurants, they head for Dave's Grill. This perennial favorite is now in its 14th year. Set on Montauk Harbor beside day-fishing boats, seafood shacks and ferries to Block Island, Dave's appears to fit right in. It has a modest, rustic exterior, but closer inspection reveals charming refinements: attractive postage-stamp gardens flanking the entrance and window boxes crowded with cascading blooms.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Ocean's Grillfish & Steak restaurant in Amagansett, Long Island (A La Carte column) (M)
lead_paragraph: THIS is the time when the sun is warm, the sea breezes are cool and life is good on the East End. Many of the folks who feel mellow, relaxed and rested after an easygoing day at the beach or on the deck and want to continue their laid-back ways at dinner are unwinding at Ocean's Grillfish & Steak in Amagansett (631-267-6980). Unlike the glitzy, celebrity-centered, expensive, often loud and crowded tourist palace Hamptons restaurants, Ocean's is a spiffy yet informal tropical beachcomber, a couple of hundred yards across the dunes from the Atlantic along the Napeague stretch at 2095 Montauk Highway.

snippet: Eric Asimov reviews Rocking Horse, Manhattan restaurant (M)
lead_paragraph: IN the mid-1990's, when Rocking Horse in Chelsea was known as Rocking Horse Cafe Mexicano, it eliminated Tex-Mex cooking from its menu in favor of what its owners, Roe DiBona and Marvin Beck, called contemporary Mexican cuisine. This was instrumental in changing the way New York looked at Mexican food. Though Rocking Horse served dishes that might not ever be seen in Mexico City, like tamales stuffed with cornmeal and sweet duck confit served in a pear and habanero sauce, it was resolute in its use of authentic seasonings. In spirit, it was indisputably Mexican.

lead_paragraph: There was an outré, apple-red-and-lavender sofa abundant with curlicues -- a mid-19th-century Anglo-Indian oddity made of rosewood inlaid with brass and bone. Adorned with reeded scrolls and inset with five medallions featuring Indian rulers, it fetched a mere $64,000. Its estimated worth: $70,000 to $90,000.
abstract: There was an outré, apple-red-and-lavender sofa abundant with curlicues -- a mid-19th-century Anglo-Indian oddity made of rosewood inlaid with brass and bone. Adorned with reeded scrolls and inset with five medallions featuring Indian rulers, it fetched a mere $64,000. Its estimated worth: $70,000 to $90,000.    There was an Italian oil painting depicting an apparently dazed, mahogany-colored man with a pipe dangling from his lips, his eyes half closed. Despite the obscurity of the artist (Antonio Rivas) and the work's indeterinate age, the bidding was frenzied. Titled ''Smoking the Pipe,'' it garnered $30,000. Its worth? Only $3,000 to $5,000, according to Sotheby's.

snippet: Anne Raver article on gathering of her family for Thanksgiving at Raver farm in Maryland; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN Capt. John Smith sailed up Chesapeake Bay in 1608, the water was so full of fish that his men could scoop them up in a frying pan. That's how the story goes anyway. The shallows were thick with clams and crabs and oysters, and on Thanksgiving, on our family farm near the bay, Baltimore's brackish harbor, we start the feast by slurping raw oysters. They're not as plentiful as in those days, of course, so we savor them all the more.

lead_paragraph: I HAD only 10 minutes to get from the train to the bus in the village of Tazawako, Japan. It took me five to find the bus station and buy my ticket to Nyuto Onsen, where I wanted to sample the hot springs. With the clock ticking, I dashed out into the village's main street, hauling my backpack, to locate the one essential item I hadn't remembered to take on my six-day hiking trip last month in northern Japan's most geothermically active region: a bottle of sake.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviewws Jake's Grille in Oceanside, New York (A La Carte column) (M)
lead_paragraph: JAKE'S GRILLE in Oceanside has many virtues. Consistency isn't one of them. It is an ambitious restaurant with a flair and creativity rarely encountered at the mid-price level. The chef, John Circharo, and his crew make their own bread and desserts including ice cream (king-size bargains at $6). There's a respectable selection of wines priced under $20. The nightly specials make for an enticing read with not-seen-elsewhere originals like braised endive cassolette; fluke Napoleon, layered with grilled vegetables; a salad with red tango and baby Lola Rosa, which are two types of lettuce; and scallion-crusted bassa, a grouper-like fish, with ''Belugian caviar lentils,'' which is not caviar but small black beans.

snippet: Miles Unger reviews Eat Art, exhibit of works made of food by German artists Joseph Beuys, Dieter Roth and Sonja Alhauser on view at Harvard's Busch-Reisinger Museum; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: ONCE it was possible to have your cake and eat it, too. This, after all, was an essential function of art: to preserve fleeting pleasures, to give permanent form to the perishable. Art's longevity was the consolation for life's too brief span. What could be more satisfying, sensually or spiritually, than a basket of wild strawberries painted by Chardin, or a tableful of apples and peaches by Cézanne? Succulent, mouthwatering and never in need of refrigeration, these fruit provide nutrition regardless of season. Their eternal perfection is a reproach to mere produce, which must be consumed or left to rot.
abstract: Miles Unger reviews Eat Art, exhibit of works made of food by German artists Joseph Beuys, Dieter Roth and Sonja Alhauser on view at Harvard's Busch-Reisinger Museum; photos (M)

snippet: Ben Brantley reviews Neil LaBute play The Shape of Things, which opens at Promenade Theater; LaBute directs; photo of Rachel Weisz and Paul Rudd (M)
lead_paragraph: The music, selections by Smashing Pumpkins played at full volume, comes at you like a raging lawn mower. Heard before ''The Shape of Things,'' the seriously contrived new play by Neil LaBute, and between every scene, the songs are loud enough to pre-empt any attempt at conversation or, for that matter, thought. They also present an implicit challenge: are you strong enough to stomach the harsh truths that await you?

snippet: William Grimes reviews restaurant scene in New York in 2001; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IN a year filled to bursting with improbable events, most of them alarming, it may be hard to make a case for restaurants as a big story, but I have to try. There were too many memorable meals, too many chefs doing inspired work and too many good new restaurants not to make the effort. Well before disaster struck in September, I was already convinced that 2001 was shaping up to be a year to remember for New York diners. The turmoil and uncertainty of the following three months did nothing to change my opinion.

snippet: David Pogue State of the Art column assesses Microsoft Corp's new Windows XP computer operating system; notes its success could spur wave of PC buying and upgrading; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IF you could choose only one word to sum up Windows XP, ''big'' would come to mind. Microsoft's new operating system is physically big, requiring two gigabytes of hard-drive space and more than an hour to install. It's big in scope, too: XP is Microsoft's attempt to merge its home line (the friendly but cranky Windows 95, 98 and Me) with its corporate line (the unattractive but rock-solid Windows NT and 2000) into a unified operating system that offers the best of both.

lead_paragraph: Here comes Jason Friedman, flying in from Southern California with just one-eighth of a master's degree. The family business needs him early, he has decided.
abstract: Here comes Jason Friedman, flying in from Southern California with just one-eighth of a master's degree. The family business needs him early, he has decided.    The six storefronts of J&R Music and Computer World, the company his parents built into an economic anchor and landmark on Park Row in Lower Manhattan, have been shut since Sept. 11. On the day of the World Trade Center attack, a thick cloud of hot, black soot blew through the doors and settled inside the DVD players and computer hard drives. Rescue workers also smashed some doors, to set up a triage center that got little use.

lead_paragraph: I HAVE been battling a mysterious weed for more than 10 years now. It first showed up in my garden in St. James on Long Island when it crept up from the marshy banks of the Nissequogue River toward my shrub roses.
abstract: I HAVE been battling a mysterious weed for more than 10 years now. It first showed up in my garden in St. James on Long Island when it crept up from the marshy banks of the Nissequogue River toward my shrub roses.     I ignored it. The locals called it water locust, and talked vaguely of it being poisonous. But it was rather pretty, its serrated compound leaves arranged in threes around a 10-inch stem, with a flower much like Queen Anne's lace.
