snippet: Novelist Jonathan Lethem's personal account of Sept 11 terrorist attacks from his vantage point in Brooklyn, and days following when he would walk to Brooklyn Heights Promenade and watch through haze at altered city amid crowd of neighbors, some w...
lead_paragraph: 1.It began for me here, in the same room where I sit now, in Boerum Hill. It began as a non sequitur crackle of sunlight thunder, on a gorgeous morning after an evening of thunderstorms. I ignored the sound, took a shower instead, wondering about the sports page: had Roger Clemens won his 20th? The phone rang, and a friend asked: ''Did you see it?'' So I went to the window, and saw. In this part of Brooklyn the towers are the nearest bit of Manhattan, easily visible from upper stories or rooftops. Neighbors commute -- excuse me, commuted -- to them by walking across the Brooklyn Bridge. Both planes had arrived by the time I looked out the window. My denial slid from the fact of it -- they're on fire, wow -- to tangential irritations, stuff I had to get done this week. I'd re-enact this denial again and again in the next hours: the mind's raw disinclination to grant this new actuality, cognitive dissonance run riot. I'd entered -- we'd all entered -- a world containing a fresh category of phenomena: the unimaginable fact.
abstract: Novelist Jonathan Lethem's personal account of Sept 11 terrorist attacks from his vantage point in Brooklyn, and days following when he would walk to Brooklyn Heights Promenade and watch through haze at altered city amid crowd of neighbors, some wearing protective face masks; recalls seeing World Trade Center twin towers built and adopting them as his own just because they were part of New York; photo of burning towers from East Williamsburg section of Brooklyn (M)

lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:    My father's recent trip to the Big Apple -- one of the first times he's left our native Saskatchewan -- was complicated by his overwhelming fear of big-city germs. Therefore, though the heat was unbearable, Dad wore his gloves absolutely everywhere we went. At the Yankee game, at Zabar's, in the subway, when we had drinks outside Tavern on the Green -- as long as we were in public and no matter how I beseeched him, the thick insulated leather gloves never came off. Finally, my girlfriend gave it a shot. ''You know, Mr. Fass,'' she said, ''it's much more likely that you'll get sick from wearing those gloves all day in this hot weather than if you took them off and exposed yourself to a little fresh air.'' Reluctantly, Dad took off his gloves. He was sick as a dog for two weeks.     Mark Fass    Dear Diary:    Some years ago, I traveled from my then home in Los Angeles to New York and decided to visit the neighborhood in Williamsburg where I had grown up. I was on the subway en route when I realized that the man sitting across the aisle from me was George Wright, one of my high school teachers.

lead_paragraph: ''You need more than luck in Shanghai,'' Rita Hayworth says darkly to Orson Welles in ''The Lady From Shanghai.''
abstract: ''You need more than luck in Shanghai,'' Rita Hayworth says darkly to Orson Welles in ''The Lady From Shanghai.''     As I drove in from Shanghai's four-year-old airport, the first sight of the city already suggested that Hayworth's motto might be ready for revision. The towers of Pudong looked like the 3-D environs of a video game, or a fleet of spaceships just landed on the east shore of the Huangpu River. The buildings weren't all fully occupied, or even tasteful, but their mirrored glass and fanciful shapes were thrilling, fearlessly dynamic.

snippet: Editorial articulates new themes candidates for New York City mayor should bring to debate over city's future; says campaign should search for gentler version of Rudolph Giuliani, who can preserve city's gains without bruising its spirit (M)
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom is that this year's mayoral campaign will be a search for a gentler version of Rudolph Giuliani, someone who can preserve the city's gains without bruising its spirit. But in fact this should be a big-picture election. The candidates will have an opportunity to move beyond Mr. Giuliani's signature issues of crime and welfare reform and outline a new agenda for a city that has to worry less about safety and more about prosperity, civic harmony, new development and infrastructure.

snippet: Stand-up comedian T C Tanis essay, scoring increase in tolls on Hudson River crossings from New Jersey into New York City to $6, holds New Jersey should start charging to enter state; offers other suggestions for New Yorkers visiting New Jersey; d...
lead_paragraph: TOLLS at the Hudson River crossings from New Jersey into New York City go up today to an outrageous $6, a 50 percent increase over what for a decade has been $4. Six dollars, which is more than the minimum hourly wage, is roughly enough for 17 toll stops on the Garden State Parkway, a Newark Bears baseball ticket, or two glossy magazines -- one, if it's the really fancy mag with the seven-figure suburban homes. Bet your E-ZPass you won't be settling into one of those abodes while shelling out a hundred and twenty a month to drive over a bridge.

lead_paragraph: For those who prefer Alpine scenery, companion rates at Interlaken are being cut by half for three January departures from SkiEurope. The first person pays $870, the other $435. For that, each gets round-trip air fare on Continental from New York to Zurich, seven nights at the three-star Chalet-Hotel Oberland, a rental car at the airport and daily breakfast buffet. A one-week Jungfrau Region ski pass costs about $171 at 1.70 Swiss francs to the dollar. Trip dates are Jan. 4 to 12, Jan. 11 to 19 and Jan. 18 to 26. Information: (800) 333-5533 or www.ski-europe.com .

snippet: William Safire column on word 'unilateralist' to characterize Bush administration's foreign policy and the use of nomenclature to put the best light on policy positions (M)
lead_paragraph: 'I hope the notion of a unilateral approach died in some people's minds here today,'' President George W. Bush told a NATO news conference in Brussels, bridling at having been saddled with the dirty diplomatic word. ''Unilateralists don't come around the table to listen to others. . . . Unilateralists don't ask opinions of world leaders.'' In case anybody didn't get his point, he gave a definition: ''A unilateralist is one that doesn't understand the role of NATO.'' Were it not for the ghost of the Nixonian ''I am not a crook,'' he would surely have added, ''I am not a unilateralist.''
abstract: William Safire column on word 'unilateralist' to characterize Bush administration's foreign policy and the use of nomenclature to put the best light on policy positions (M)

lead_paragraph: IN summertime, the fish are jumpin', as the ''Porgy and Bess'' libretto by DuBose Heyward and Ira Gershwin reminds us. Nobody, I think, has interviewed any fish -- not even the notoriously talkative dolphins -- to learn why they start jumpin' joyfully at the summer solstice. In Long Island waters, perhaps those jumpin' fish are sayin' it is better to swim in a sauce with white wine than in chilly waters. They'll find out soon enough, as will their shellfish brethren.

lead_paragraph: THERE were grumblings when, late last month, Judge Matthew F. Cooper of Manhattan Criminal Court dismissed gambling charges against a defendant accused of operating a three-card monte setup on the street, arguing that the game was poised not on chance, but on skill.
abstract: THERE were grumblings when, late last month, Judge Matthew F. Cooper of Manhattan Criminal Court dismissed gambling charges against a defendant accused of operating a three-card monte setup on the street, arguing that the game was poised not on chance, but on skill.    Judge Cooper was, however, correct. Three-card monte leaves absolutely nothing to chance. When you bet that you can keep track of a card, typically the ace of spades, as it and two of its siblings are rapidly shuttled face-down around the table by the dealer, you are not hoping for any kind of mere luck, but are proudly using your money to back up the high opinion you maintain of your eagle eye and powers of concentration. You are, that is to say, a fool.

abstract: WATCH out for the Nazi fabrics.'' The costume designer William Ivey Long sidestepped bolts of drab brown material thrown only steps inside the doorway of his genteelly chaotic Chelsea brownstone. He was leading a visitor through the ground-floor office, past the several desks where he and his two assistants work, sometimes around the clock, and into his garden.    Mr. Long practically owns Broadway these days: he has seven shows running -- ''Cabaret,''  ''Chicago,''  ''Contact,''  ''The Music Man,''  ''Annie Get Your Gun,''  ''Seussical'' and now, the splashiest of all, the new smash Mel Brooks musical, for which he just earned his seventh Tony nomination. (He won for ''Crazy for You'' and ''Nine.'')

lead_paragraph: Anthony is standing in front of a spiffy row of Manhattan brownstones, holding a sign that says ''Housing Assistance.'' Kurt, smiling adorably, is posing on a school playground, and his sign reads ''Professional Development.'' Last but not least is Tamara, perched on a surprisingly clean subway platform with another enticing sign: ''$13,600 Grant.''
abstract: Anthony is standing in front of a spiffy row of Manhattan brownstones, holding a sign that says ''Housing Assistance.'' Kurt, smiling adorably, is posing on a school playground, and his sign reads ''Professional Development.'' Last but not least is Tamara, perched on a surprisingly clean subway platform with another enticing sign: ''$13,600 Grant.''    This is what the New York City school system has to offer prospective teachers, at least in the eyes of a high-powered advertising agency charged with luring as many certified teachers as possible to the city's schools by September. The Board of Education is paying the agency, TBWA/Chiat/Day, $8 million for a series of print, radio and television advertisements, most of which will start next week in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

snippet: Article describes combination of marketing and myth-making that has been used to bring Billy Collins from relative obscurity in 1993 to America's poet laureate, with thousands of people clamoring to attend his readings; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: TWO weeks ago, the Poetry Center of Chicago sponsored a reading by Billy Collins at the Chicago Historical Society. The last time the center had invited him to read, in 1993, he had been a relatively obscure poet whose last volume, ''Questions About Angels,'' was on its way out of print. This time, Mr. Collins, who was raised in Jackson Heights, Queens, and teaches in the city university system at Lehman College in the Bronx, caused the literary equivalent of Beatlemania.

lead_paragraph: LONG before Martha Stewart made the suburbs safe for country chic, Gladys Taber ruled the rural roost in Connecticut. Her home base was Stillmeadow, an agricultural enclave on Sanford Road in the southeastern corner of Southbury.
abstract: LONG before Martha Stewart made the suburbs safe for country chic, Gladys Taber ruled the rural roost in Connecticut. Her home base was Stillmeadow, an agricultural enclave on Sanford Road in the southeastern corner of Southbury.    Mrs. Taber's farm, her 17th-century farmhouse, the village of Southbury and the surrounding countryside became her writerly muses, beginning in 1931, when she moved up from Manhattan, and continuing until her death at age 81 in 1980.

snippet: David Pogue column evaluates three new palmtops that run on Microsoft's Pocket PC 2002 operating system; they are Toshiba Genio E, Compaq iPaq and HP Jornada; photos; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: TODAY is a big day for hand-held computing nuts. It marks the release of Pocket PC 2002, Microsoft's next-generation operating system for pocket computers, as well as the debut of several palmtops that run it. Their makers -- Compaq, Toshiba and Hewlett-Packard -- have much to celebrate: they have succeeded in thinking small. But Microsoft continues to think big, which is not always a good thing in machines with three-inch screens.

lead_paragraph: THE New Yorker magazine should have waited until Mother's Day to run a recent cartoon that sent a shiver of recognition through women (and some men) of a certain age.
abstract: THE New Yorker magazine should have waited until Mother's Day to run a recent cartoon that sent a shiver of recognition through women (and some men) of a certain age.    At a park bench, where once they compared notes on their children, two middle-aged women are flanked by older, sour-faced look-alikes -- their mothers. In the caption, one friend is speaking: ''Seventy-seven,'' she says. ''How about yours?''

snippet: Ann Powers reviews performance by singer Amy Correia at Fez; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night at Fez, Amy Correia risked a platitude and ended up with an elucidation. Accompanied by Gerri Sutyak on cello, she tackled ''La Vie en Rose,'' the world's classiest saloon song and the legendary Edith Piaf's signature. It takes audacity for a young American to claim such a weighty text, but Ms. Correia succeeded, using the song to help define her own talent.
abstract: Ann Powers reviews performance by singer Amy Correia at Fez; photo (M)

snippet: Nina Simonds Choice Tables column reviews sampling of Seoul, South Korea, restaurants; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IT'S been 20 years since my last visit to Seoul, and in that time, the city has transformed itself into a sophisticated, cosmopolitan center with broad avenues that are reminiscent of Western cities. Despite the glamour of soaring skyscrapers and chic designer boutiques, its spirit remains distinctly Asian -- from the thriving all-night markets where vendors offer extraordinary bargains on every type of goods imaginable to the charming traditional teahouses where customers trade gossip, nibble on sweet rice pastries and sip fragrant tea.
abstract: Nina Simonds Choice Tables column reviews sampling of Seoul, South Korea, restaurants; photos (M)

snippet: Eric Asimov, in $25 and Under column, reviews La Esquina Criolla, in Corona, Queens (M)
lead_paragraph: TRAVELING along the main routes of Jackson Heights and Corona, Queens, is like taking a trip to the United Nations. Flags and cultures of disparate countries abound. While there are video stores and clothing shops, most of the storefronts are devoted to food. In a single block you can find a dozen different chilies in a Mexican grocery, an artist's palette of spices in an Indian market, and restaurants, endless restaurants.

lead_paragraph: TUSCAN STEAK'S name says a lot about its intentions. In three compressed syllables, it manages to press two big pleasure buttons. Tuscany, which now has the power of an international brand, seduces with the promise of simple, accessible food and superb wine suffused with a romantic glow. Steak presents Americans with the food they love best: slabs of red meat.

snippet: Is fish that takes a week to get from sea to market really fresh? Lori Whitmill and Sherry Tuttle, who own Rose Fisheries in Sitka, Alaska, look at freshness another way. They go out on their fishing boat, the Rose, to catch Alaskan king and coho ...
lead_paragraph: Is fish that takes a week to get from sea to market really fresh? Lori Whitmill and Sherry Tuttle, who own Rose Fisheries in Sitka, Alaska, look at freshness another way. They go out on their fishing boat, the Rose, to catch Alaskan king and coho salmon with hook and line, not in nets, and then gut and flash-freeze them on board. But selling the fish to consumers obsessed with freshness (which, to most, means never frozen) is another matter, as Ms. Tuttle found a few weeks ago, when she gave out samples at Fairway on Broadway. Skeptical customers were pleasantly surprised after tasting the fish.
abstract: Is fish that takes a week to get from sea to market really fresh? Lori Whitmill and Sherry Tuttle, who own Rose Fisheries in Sitka, Alaska, look at freshness another way. snippet: International team of astrophysicists discovers that basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as universe ages, surprising finding that could challenge fundamental assumptions about workings of cosmos; research team led by...
lead_paragraph: An international team of astrophysicists has discovered that the basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as the universe ages, a surprising finding that could rewrite physics textbooks and challenge fundamental assumptions about the workings of the cosmos.
abstract: International team of astrophysicists discovers that basic laws of nature as understood today may be changing slightly as universe ages, surprising finding that could challenge fundamental assumptions about workings of cosmos; research team led by Dr John K Webb used Keck telescope in Hawaii, world's largest single telescope, to study behavior of metallic atoms in gas clouds as far away from Earth as 12 billion light years; observations revealed patters of light absorption that team could not explain without assuming change in a basic constant of nature, called fine structure constant, involving strength of attraction between electically charged particles; if confirmed, finding could mean that other constants, like speed of light, might also have changed over history of universe; could also add credence to unproven theory of physics called string theory, which predicts that extra dimensions exist in fabric of space; implications are so far-reaching that many scientists are expressing skepticism that results will stand test of time, and even researchers on project are being deliberately cautious in presenting findings; research will be published in Physical Review Letters, field's most prestigious journal; chart explains fine structure content (M)

headline.main: Anything Can Change, It Seems, Even an Immutable Law of Nature

Bush's slim lead in Florida.''

lead_paragraph: IN honor of Earth Day, our text is ''RRR You Ready?'' the new waste-reduction manual, weighing five pounds and prepared at a cost of $2 million, that has been distributed to public schools by the New York City Department of Sanitation. For safety purposes, let's begin with Chapter 4, ''How I can be a TrashMaster!''
abstract: IN honor of Earth Day, our text is ''RRR You Ready?'' the new waste-reduction manual, weighing five pounds and prepared at a cost of $2 million, that has been distributed to public schools by the New York City Department of Sanitation. For safety purposes, let's begin with Chapter 4, ''How I can be a TrashMaster!''    This chapter instructs students who have learned the modern three R's -- reduce, reuse, recycle -- to ''share'' their knowledge with their families. That means getting their families to follow dozens of rules, including this one: ''Return wire hangers and plastic bags to the dry cleaners.''

lead_paragraph: More than 100 hotels in the Los Angeles area are offering two nights for the price of one through February. The program includes Los Angeles, Pasadena, Long Beach, Santa Monica, West Hollywood and Marina del Rey. And when guests check in, they will receive TheLAcard, good for 10 to 20 percent off at participating restaurants. Other benefits include a child's admission with each paid adult admission to Universal Studios Hollywood, shopping discounts from various stores in the Beverly Center and the Century City Shopping Center and two-for-one admission to the Norton Simon Museum, the Petersen Automotive Museum and others. Hotel rooms are subject to availability. For details, (800) 228-2452 or www.visitlanow.com .

snippet: Joanne Starkey reviews Adirondack Grill in Glen Cove, Long Island; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IT is the décor at the Adirondack Grill that makes the biggest impression. Appropriately situated on Forest Avenue in Glen Cove, the newcomer makes a statement even before diners enter. lead_paragraph: I don't believe in public confessions, but I think you should know that my watch only tells time. It doesn't have a nocturnal sky chart, a perpetual calendar or a chime system that exactly replicates the tone and rhythm of the bells of Big Ben, the way the Patek Philippe Star Caliber 2000 watch does. Next to the Star Caliber 2000, which is sold in sets of four and costs $7.5 million a set, my own watch is a horological disgrace.

snippet: The Ladera Resort, in the mountains above Soufrière in southern St. Lucia, has a No News package with some extras thrown in.
lead_paragraph: For those who have been watching cable-news channels for too long, the Ladera Resort, in the mountains above Soufrière in southern St. Lucia, has a No News package with some extras thrown in. It offers a two-night stay in a suite with a private plunge pool and no TV, phone or radio and no fourth wall (that's to provide a view of the Piton Mountains, without anyone's getting a view of you). With no links to the outside world, guests will have to wait to use the $25 gift certificate for Amazon.com that is also included, as are a guided half-day tropical rain-forest walk (valued at $30) and a breakfast each morning. Rates are $500 suite until Dec. 17 and $790 Dec. 18 to April 17. Not included are taxes, which are 18 percent. Information: (800) 738- 4752 or www.ladera-stlucia.com .

lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:    Word of Perry Como's death reminded me of an incident in the early 1940's at the Glen Oaks Country Club on Long Island. A friend of mine arrived at the club without having arranged a golf game in advance, but he found three members about to tee off. He knew two of them, and the third was introduced as Perry Como, a new member. My friend, who always wanted to know everything about everyone, asked the man what his business was. The man said he was a singer, and my friend, thinking he was being spoofed, replied, ''If you're a singer, then I'm Rudy Vallee.'' When the new member insisted that he was a singer, my friend asked him to sing something, which he did. When he finished, my friend said, ''I still say if you're a singer, then I'm Rudy Vallee.'' Nothing more was said, but when my friend arrived home he asked his wife if she had ever heard of a singer named Perry Como. Her excited reply made him realize that he had made a mistake, and he prepared to apologize the next time they met. The following morning he returned to the club, and when he arrived at his locker he found the following message in large letters: ''GOOD MORNING RUDY VALLEE.''   Irving J. Volk      Phyllis Robbins was walking on the Upper East Side when she saw a woman looking into the windows of a fashionable shop while her dog strained at its leash. The woman obviously had had enough of the tugging. She looked at the dog and snapped: ''I let you stop to look at things you want to. Why can't I?''

snippet: Jan Benzel article on visiting Tyler Arboretum, Philadelphia Zoo and Historic Bartram's Garden, garden sites in or near Philadelphia; map; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IN mid-April, when only the crocuses and snowdrops were out in New York and you had to look hard for the occasional brave daffodil, I jumped in the car and headed to the notch in the southeastern border of Pennsylvania, where I grew up and where spring had a head start. Along with 210,000 others, I had seen the season in previews indoors in March at the fabulously splashy Philadelphia Flower Show, where 10 acres of displays ran the gamut from elegant to wacky. Now I wanted to see spring's grand entrance, late as it was, and I had three gardens in mind.

lead_paragraph: It has been four years since securities regulators found that practices by brokerage firms in the Nasdaq stock market were harmful to individual investors. And while Nasdaq executives have tried during that time to make it a fairer place for investors to trade, a study released yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission concluded that the market had a ways to go before it could be considered truly investor friendly.
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission study concludes Nasdaq stock market has a ways to go before it can be considered truly investor friendly; finds that those who buy and sell Nasdaq stocks pay significantly higher costs, on average, than those who trade on New York Stock Exchange; finds that investors who place orders for stocks at prices known as limit orders are significantly less likely to have their orders executed on Nasdaq than they are on New York Stock Exchange; SEC chairman, Arthur Levitt, says that for customers interested in betting better prices on their trades than prevailing market offers, interaction with other investors is key, speech at Stanford University Law School (Market Place column) (M)

lead_paragraph: AZALEAS really need to be in a woods, that's all there is to it. When you see them massed up a wooded hill, as I did last week, at the National Arboretum in Washington, you can almost like them.
abstract: AZALEAS really need to be in a woods, that's all there is to it. When you see them massed up a wooded hill, as I did last week, at the National Arboretum in Washington, you can almost like them.    I grew up with a bad impression of azaleas, because my father planted one of those hot pink varieties on the edge of the grass, way too close to a golden rain tree. Picture bright yellow cascading over bubblegum pink. Placement might not be everything, but it's a lot.

snippet: Brick house on campus of University of Virginia that was designed by Thomas Jefferson is now home of School of Architecture dean, Karen Van Lengen; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: ONCE again, in the Great Hide and Go Seek Garden, Karen Van Lengen was ''it.'' She counted to 40 as she sat on a bench with her eyes closed at Thomas Jefferson's Academical Village -- better known as the Lawn at the University of Virginia. The Lawn forms the neo-Classical heart of the university's sprawling campus. Jefferson's master plan put student dormitories, faculty houses (pavilions) and colonnades on either side of a quadrangle. At one end he placed his rotunda, modeled on the Pantheon in Rome.

snippet: Susan Allen Toth travel article on winter trip to Hilton Hawaiian Village on Waikiki Beach, Hawaii; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: ON cold, gray days, I sometimes daydream about the Super Pool. As I stare out my window, I see myself sliding peacefully through clear water, tinted blue from its painted floor and surrounding brilliantly colored tiles, as the white-hot sun glints through palm trees, scarlet and coral hibiscus, and flowering birds of paradise. Few others ever seem to swim in this free-form 10,000-square-foot pool at the Hilton Hawaiian Village on Waikiki Beach. The giant pool is edged with what seems like an acre of empty recliners, covered mainly by large green towels staking obscure absentee claims. By midafternoon, perhaps 30 people in tropical-print shorts or bikinis are lounging poolside. They read paperbacks with gaudy covers and sip drinks of dark, fruity liquids crowned by little paper umbrellas, but they seldom go into the water. Savoring the pool all to myself, I just swim.
abstract: Susan Allen Toth travel article on winter trip to Hilton Hawaiian Village on Waikiki Beach, Hawaii; photos (L)

snippet: Margaret Talbot, senior fellow at New America Foundation, offers thoughts on what to tell her inquisitive young son about terrorist attacks on New York City and Washington; stymied by sheer monstrousness of attack, she tries to find comfort in mun...
lead_paragraph: Because airline travel has become a matter of tedium or fear for adults, it is easy to forget that for children, it was something magical. For them, it was friendly visits to the cockpit, stick-on wings and half-forbidden sodas given to them by flight attendants, cotton-candy clouds outside and a toy world below. National Airport is one of the few in the country you can fly into and know you are not gliding over some anonymous landscape but are nearly home, if home it is. You follow the silver strand of the Potomac -- and then suddenly, look, there's the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial; your kids press their noses against the window, and they squeal because, yes, they're sure they can see their house now. Isn't that it, glistening like a good-luck penny?
abstract: Margaret Talbot, senior fellow at New America Foundation, offers thoughts on what to tell her inquisitive young son about terrorist attacks on New York City and Washington; stymied by sheer monstrousness of attack, she tries to find comfort in mundane things, but finds everything has changed and is tinged by grief; photo of Pentagon taken Sept 13 (M)

lead_paragraph: A cluster of five stark white towers that dominate the Albany skyline receded behind the treetops as our Dutch Apple cruise boat headed south on the Hudson River. Over the loudspeaker, the captain informed us that one of them, the Corning Tower, at 42 stories, was the tallest building in the state outside of New York City. A white-haired woman in a Yankees cap pointed to one of the towers and said to her friend, ''That's where I renewed my driver's license.''

lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:    Given the City Council controversy surrounding ferrets, of all things, I'd like to share an experience I had at the Union Square Greenmarket. People were out in droves with leashed dogs and kids in strollers, and I'd taken along MadMax, my curious-about-everything champagne-colored ferret, in collar and leash.    Max was helping me select apples when someone tugged at my arm. ''Excuse me please,'' said the voice. ''What is that beautiful creature?'' I looked down and saw the tiniest old woman I'd ever seen. It was amazing that she had made her way through the crowd. In a kerchief and full skirt, she looked like someone out of a fairy tale.

lead_paragraph: Canadian Concern Is Seen In Deal for Unilever Unit
abstract: Canadian Concern Is Seen In Deal for Unilever Unit  George Weston, the Canadian food conglomerate, is expected to buy Unilever's bakery division for about $1.7 million in cash, adding Thomas' English Muffins to its brands, which include Girl Scout cookies, executives close to the negotiations said.    The deal could be announced as early as today, ending an auction that attracted some of the industry's biggest rivals, including Sara Lee, Earthgrains and Grupo Bimbo of Mexico, to compete for brands like Entenmann's and Boboli. lead_paragraph: The Spanish-language television network Univision has been putting up billboards all over New York City. One in particular struck me, given the census figures showing Hispanics to be the country's largest minority. It called Univision as ''American as flan.'' lead_paragraph: At 8:30 one recent morning, Carol O'Neill sat in her Jeep Cherokee, wrapping the ends of her blond hair around fat blue curlers. She wore the same black knit suit with brass buttons that she had worn almost every day for two weeks. Beside her was a manila folder, containing a Post-it Note with neat cursive script reading ''Stacey McGowan, Grace Memorial Church, 10:30 a.m.,'' and directions from Huntington Bay, on Long Island, where Mrs. O'Neill lives, to Nyack, N.Y., where the church is.

snippet: Ron Jenkins article on International Theater School of Jacques Lecoq in Paris, a school of clowning, improvisation and commedia dell'arte that has been great incubator for theatrical innovation and has had profound impact on theater; says that bec...
lead_paragraph: THE International Theater School of Jacques Lecoq is artfully ensconced behind a labyrinth of nondescript courtyards in the bustling commercial center of Paris's 10th Arrondissement, not far from the Gare du Nord. The drab metal door at 57 rue Faubourg St.-Denis gives no hint of providing access to one of the most influential theater training programs of the last half century -- a school of clowning, improvisation and commedia dell'arte whose graduates have collectively redefined the boundaries of physical theater for their generation. The building's unusual history is evoked by the sounds of shrieking, howling and grunting that echo through the corridors as students prepare for their lessons.
abstract: Ron Jenkins article on International Theater School of Jacques Lecoq in Paris, a school of clowning, improvisation and commedia dell'arte that has been great incubator for theatrical innovation and has had profound impact on theater; says that because Lecoq, who died in 1999, insisted that students develop their own individual style, there is no clearly definable Lecoq style, but that his poetic approach to movement has influenced such theater pioneers as Julie Taymor, Ariane Mnouchkine, Theatre de Complicite, Cirque du Soleil, Mummenschanz, Footsbarn Traveling Theater of France, Theatre de la Jeune Lune, Geoffrey Rush, Steven Berkoff and Yasmina Reza; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: On a recent visit to a London antique dealer, David Kamansky, director of the Pacific Asia Museum in Pasadena, Calif., was presented with a shoe box. Inside, covered with flimsy paper, were fragments of a 2,000-year-old ivory casket, decorated with intricate Indian carvings, unmistakably part of the famous Begram collection that once belonged to the Kabul Museum in Afghanistan.
abstract: Fabulous art treasures of Afghanistan from Greek, Buddhist and Islamic civilizations were presumed gone, destroyed by 20 years of war, economic desperation and, most recently, by Taliban's fundamentalist brand of Islam; but during last decade, much of art has made its way out of Afghanistan to North America, Western Europe and Japan; it has been found in places at end of road for smuggling; pieces have been plundered by warring factions in Afghanistan, passed into Pakistan or former Soviet lands to north, and made their way onto international art market; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: Q. My mouse freezes frequently or has trouble moving and I have to reboot the computer to get it to work again. What might be causing this?
abstract: Q. My mouse freezes frequently or has trouble moving and I have to reboot the computer to get it to work again. What might be causing this?    A. A mouse's misbehavior can be caused by several things, from conflicting software to dirt in its rollerball, so troubleshooting the problem may take some time. If restarting the computer seems to clear up the problem temporarily, odds are the mouse glitch lies with software.

snippet: In Shakespeare, as in life, the apple doesn't fall very far from the tree. Thirty or so years ago, the high point of Peter Hall's management of the Royal Shakespeare Company was his epic "Wars of the Roses." Now, as befits a tougher and economi
lead_paragraph: In Shakespeare, as in life, the apple doesn't fall very far from the tree. Thirty or so years ago, the high point of Peter Hall's management of the Royal Shakespeare Company was his epic "Wars of the Roses." Now, as befits a tougher and economically tighter age, his son Edward comes to the Watermill in Newbury with a fighting team of 12 male actors and a version of the three parts of "Henry VI" which amazingly they get through in rather less than four hours, as against the eight or nine to which we have become accustomed and which the RSC will soon be giving us again at the Young Vic.

lead_paragraph: THREE women, their blond hair ironed straight, tore through a rack of denim jeans as if the pockets were stuffed with $100 bills. Nearby, a cluster of fashion editors in teetering heels circled a cozy Henley sweater. It was a must, they agreed. Disco was blasting. Think of the fervor of an exclusive sample sale. Multiply by two. Add cocktails, and you have a fashion phenomenon -- the shopping party.
abstract: THREE women, their blond hair ironed straight, tore through a rack of denim jeans as if the pockets were stuffed with $100 bills. Nearby, a cluster of fashion editors in teetering heels circled a cozy Henley sweater. It was a must, they agreed. Disco was blasting. Think of the fervor of an exclusive sample sale. Multiply by two. Add cocktails, and you have a fashion phenomenon -- the shopping party.    At that party, in late February, Stefani Greenfield, an owner of Scoop, a boutique in SoHo, turned her shop into a club of sorts. There was a D.J. There were apple martinis. There was finger food. More than 200 women were crammed into the small space as men wearing black suits and high-tech headsets patrolled the room providing security. It was the debut of Marc by Marc Jacobs, the designer's new lower-end line, and the women were there to buy.

lead_paragraph: In the woods just north of Main Street billions of hairy invaders are stealing the season, one leaf at a time.
abstract: In the woods just north of Main Street billions of hairy invaders are stealing the season, one leaf at a time.    It began in the early spring when billions of gypsy moths, which start as caterpillars, began munching on their favorite flavors, the broad-leaved deciduous trees like white oaks and hickory. But there are so many bugs this year -- 10 times more than last year -- they quickly exhausted their predilections and moved to the apple trees and pines, wisteria, sassafras and dogwoods.

abstract: Merciless and stubborn summer drought leaves almost 1.5 million of poorest farmers in Central America with no crops to sell or food to eat; from Nicaragua to Guatemala, many of region's poorest people have been reduced to scavenging; officials estimate at least 700,000 people have lost at least half of their crops; Honduras has declared emergency, but other countries have tried to minimize severity of problem; mixed and delayed responses, as well as continued dependence on emergency food aid, point to persistent inability of region's leaders to prepare for disasters and provide for many who live on edge; aid workers and disaster experts say instead of considering drought isolated emergency, officials must begin looking at long-term rural development needs; maps; photo (M)

snippet: William Grimes surveys London's percolating restaurant scene; some notable newcomers mentioned; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: IT'S easy, looking across the ocean, to see London as a distorted reflection of New York. The key industries are the same, the fashions and the slang overlap, and the dining scene, to an uncanny degree, seems to follow the same script: all boom, no bust. The pound is weak, financial markets are unsettled, but nothing seems to slow down the food economy. Restaurants keep opening, diners keep filling them, and no one can figure out how long the boom can continue, what the next food trend will be or who all these people are.

lead_paragraph: As of December, Bill Nguyen had nearly everything he needed to start a successful business. He had a grand vision for the post-PC world: the current technobabble of cell phones, PDA's, pagers and other wireless gadgets could be woven into a unified global data-information network by a single company offering the right software. He had a proven record; at age 29, he had already been a key player in five start-ups, three of which had gone public. He had $34 million in venture capital and 60 eager employees. What he still didn't have, with his company's March inaugural date just two months away, was a name.
abstract: As of December, Bill Nguyen had nearly everything he needed to start a successful business. He had a grand vision for the post-PC world: the current technobabble of cell phones, PDA's, pagers and other wireless gadgets could be woven into a unified global data-information network by a single company offering the right software. He had a proven record; at age 29, he had already been a key player in five start-ups, three of which had gone public. He had $34 million in venture capital and 60 eager employees. What he still didn't have, with his company's March inaugural date just two months away, was a name.     With the Nasdaq's swoons causing widespread intestinal flutter, Nguyen knew a lot would hang on the first impression his company made. He wanted a name that would radiate strength and credibility, something with a dawn-of-an-era feel. He didn't even know where to start.

snippet: Jeffrey Steingarten Op-Ed article on scare stories and alarmist reports on food-borne illnesses, which he says are 'ruining America's dinner'; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Do you remember that food scare a few years ago when everybody was in a twist about the dangers of eating raw shellfish? I was having dinner around that time with an athletic friend, a captain of industry who showed up proudly wrapped in bandages and slings. He had earned these by crashing into a large shrub on the slopes of Aspen. He needed help turning the pages of his menu. And then he refused to share my lavish platter of cold, plump, briny, crisp and succulent oysters. ''Raw shellfish,'' he gulped. ''Don't you read the papers?''

lead_paragraph: PASSIONATE MINDS: Women Rewriting the World, by Claudia Roth Pierpont. (Vintage, $13.) These brief profiles of women writers like Gertrude Stein, Ayn Rand, Eudora Welty and Doris Lessing, all originally published in The New Yorker, are unified by their subjects' intense need to transcend the limitations of their own lives through language and storytelling. The book is an ''adroit melding of biography and criticism'' that ''sparkles with intelligence, wit and human interest,'' Morris Dickstein wrote in the Book Review last year.
abstract: PASSIONATE MINDS: Women Rewriting the World, by Claudia Roth Pierpont. (Vintage, $13.) These brief profiles of women writers like Gertrude Stein, Ayn Rand, Eudora Welty and Doris Lessing, all originally published in The New Yorker, are unified by their subjects' intense need to transcend the limitations of their own lives through language and storytelling. The book is an ''adroit melding of biography and criticism'' that ''sparkles with intelligence, wit and human interest,'' Morris Dickstein wrote in the Book Review last year.    EVERYTHING YOU KNOW, by Zo Heller. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $12.95.) Willy Muller is a reptilian celebrity biographer, misanthrope and all-round scuzzy character haunted by the ghost of his estranged daughter, who before her suicide mailed him every journal she'd written since she was 9. Writing here last year, Jeff Giles called this ''an acerbic, sneakily touching novel'' that at its best ''calls to mind Martin Amis's phosphorescently nasty oeuvre.''    DARWIN'S WORMS, by Adam Phillips. (Basic Books, $13.) A noted British child psychotherapist reflects on Darwin's lifelong interest in earthworms and Freud's fascination with death, both of which offer cause for celebration in a world abandoned by God. ''Almost invariably lively and entertaining,'' Phillips's essays ''are directed as well toward instructing their audience,'' Steven Marcus said in these pages in 2000.    WINSTON AND CLEMENTINE: The Personal Letters of the Churchills. Edited by Mary Soames. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $16.) Winston Churchill and his wife, Clementine, were devoted pen pals throughout 57 years of marriage, as this huge volume edited by their daughter attests. His ''manly, buoyant style is displayed to great effect,'' Thomas Mallon wrote here in 1999, while ''Clementine . . . can bring Nancy Mitford to mind.'' Churchill Wanted Dead or Alive, by Celia Sandys (Carroll & Graf, $14), is a colorful account of the young Churchill's experiences as a newspaper correspondent in the Boer War, including his escape from a prisoner of war camp. The ''fascinating narrative,'' as put together by his granddaughter, ''may be the romantic stuff of Victorian adventure fiction, but it has the virtue of being true,'' David Murray wrote here in 2000.    AFRICAN FOLKTALES: Traditional Stories of the Black World. Selected and retold by Roger D. Abrahams. (Pantheon, $18.) An accomplished Africanist plumbs the oral tradition of tribal families throughout the sub-Sahara in this revised anthology of earthy and comedic tales of magic, sultans, ghosts, lovers and animals that behave like people. ''The result is a rousing good read,'' Jason Berry said in the Book Review in 1983.    A CONSPIRACY OF PAPER, by David Liss. (Ballantine, $14.) This engaging first novel revolves around a mixed bag of 18th-century characters at the time of the South Sea Bubble, the first stock market crash in the English-speaking world. ''What makes 'A Conspiracy of Paper' so readable is that Liss manages to create a number of arresting side plots featuring everything from the London underworld to boxing to social mores to English anti-Semitism,'' James Polk wrote in these pages last year.    THE BLIND SIDE OF THE HEART, by Michael C. White. (Cliff Street/HarperCollins, $13.) The narrator of this unconventional whodunit is Maggie Quinn, a blunt-spoken housekeeper who wrestles with drink and doubt when her employer, a Roman Catholic priest who once rescued her sanity, is indicted for the murder of an altar boy they both loved. In 1999 our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, admired ''the cruel beauty'' of White's ''spare, unflinching prose.''    MORMON AMERICA: The Power and the Promise, by Richard N. Ostling and Joan K. Ostling. (HarperSanFrancisco, $17.) The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, founded by an itinerant treasure hunter from upstate New York in 1830, has a global membership of more than 10 million. This primer, which sorts through the doctrines and practices of the Mormon faith, ''is eminently fair, well researched and exhaustive,'' Timothy Egan wrote here last year.    THE MAGIC KINGDOM, by Stanley Elkin. (Dalkey Archive, $12.95.) In this crazy quilt of a novel, a man mourning the loss of his 12-year-old son leads a group of terminally ill children on a trip from England to Disney World. ''Part sick joke, part lyrical meditation on the nature of disease,'' the comic tale ''is both hysterical and profound,'' Max Apple said here in 1985.   Scott Veale

lead_paragraph: IT would be hard to imagine a plainer name for a restaurant than Irving on Irving. In fact, flash is the last thing you'll find at this little corner restaurant. Its owner also owns the Inn at Irving Place, a small and luxurious hotel next door, as well as Lady Mendl's Tea Parlor, two places that stress their grown-up appeal rather than pander to the fake-martini and pounding-bass crowd. In this company, Irving on Irving is like a cautious teenager whose idea of rebellion is to wear sneakers to school with his khakis.

snippet: Summer is here in New York City, which means that as locals begin the annual exodus to their weekend shares in the Hamptons, they are freeing up space for the rest of us to really enjoy the city. Suddenly, walking the streets and enjoying a day of...
lead_paragraph: Summer is here in New York City, which means that as locals begin the annual exodus to their weekend shares in the Hamptons, they are freeing up space for the rest of us to really enjoy the city. Suddenly, walking the streets and enjoying a day of perfect weather is possible without having to weave through crowds of people. Getting sought-after restaurant reservations is a little easier and, if for some reason you're driving, the odds are good you'll find a spot where you can park your car. The summer here is a magical blend of outdoor eateries, free concerts, festivals, walking the miles of recently paved paths along the Hudson River and rowboating in Central Park.

lead_paragraph: LAST Thursday night, Katie Brophy, 26, invited colleagues over to her place for drinks. Ever since Sept. 11, such escapist rituals -- a glass of wine, watching television on the sofa with good company -- have become precious affirmations of normalcy. But Ms. Brophy's home, once Battery Park City, is now the Royalton hotel, where it's easy to feel outwitted by a bathroom fixture, and where the Kit Kat in the minifridge costs $6.

lead_paragraph: I HAVE been to the historic house (circa 1858) at 1441 Old Northern Boulevard in Roslyn so often I could lead tours. The restaurants come and go, but the elegant Art Deco mirrors are a constant. In the last decade, this lovely building has been home to at least six different establishments. (The most recent was Giorgio.)

lead_paragraph: If you are like most people I know, chances are you are thoroughly confused about cholesterol and what you have to do to reduce your chances of suffering a heart attack or stroke. For those who must take cholesterol-lowering drugs, the confusion has been compounded by the recall this month of a leading medication, Baycol, after 31 deaths from kidney failure caused by excessive muscle breakdown.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Craft, Manhattan restaurant; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: CRAFT invites diners to take a trip. The destination is a simpler, cleaner, more honest America, a place where the corn is bright yellow, the bread exhales clouds of yeasty sweetness and the fish swim in water as pure as Évian. It's a vision of food heaven, a land of strong, pure flavors and back-to-basics cooking techniques. It sounds wonderful. But as any motorist knows, the trip to bountiful often seems to involve a few twists and turns, dead ends and unmarked roads that can leave you cursing the map.
abstract: William Grimes reviews Craft, Manhattan restaurant; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: UP in the penthouse of the West Chelsea restaurant the Park on a recent Thursday night, the 20-something host, who looked fresh off the set of ''Boogie Nights,'' in hip-hugger jeans and a tight decal T-shirt, was obviously stressed. The room didn't have the right mix of cool; it was mobbed with blown-out blondes in frayed jean miniskirts and designer stilettos. He radioed an S O S down to the doorman guarding the bottom of the stairs.

snippet: Article on grueling, hot and sometimes hazardous work involved in LIE/HOV Capacity Improvement Project, one of biggest and most extensive transportation projects ever undertaken on Long Island; decade-long project, expected to be completed in 2004...
lead_paragraph: IT was a fresh, windy day in May on the Long Island Expressway service road at New Hyde Park Road. Some telephone technicians were busy shifting their wires to span a recently completed temporary bridge across the expressway. A machinist operating an eight-ton pile driver was pounding steel sheeting into the ground for a retaining wall, creating cave-in protection for workers finishing the foundation for the bridge. And Tony Rodriguez, a general foreman, and Orlando Frade, a labor foreman, stood surveying their project, which will carry traffic across the expressway until a new permanent bridge is ready at the end of November.
abstract: Article on grueling, hot and sometimes hazardous work involved in LIE/HOV Capacity Improvement Project, one of biggest and most extensive transportation projects ever undertaken on Long Island; decade-long project, expected to be completed in 2004, is adding 41 miles of high-occupancy-vehicle lanes and replacing or modifying 61 highway overpasses, 45 service roads and more than 100 on or off ramps; workers and supervisors comment; photos (M)

snippet: David Corcoran reviews An American Bistro in Nutley, NJ; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: AN AMERICAN BISTRO is the sort of restaurant that defiantly refuses to put on airs. It is what it is. Even its name is a kind of dare: more Italian-American than American, more trattoria than bistro, it was christened when the chef and owner, a homegrown Nutley guy named Ken Mahon, heard a friend say that a place with such a nondescript name could never succeed.

snippet: Grace Glueck reviews master drawings from Cleveland Museum, now on exhibit at Morgan Library; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: It's only an arm, but what an arm! Drawn with brush point on blue paper, this slim but shapely limb is bent at the elbow and supports a supple hand slightly curved around an apple. It is -- what else? -- the arm of Eve, made in 1507 by Albrecht Dürer (1471-1528) in preparation for a pair of life-size paintings now owned by the Prado in Madrid depicting the fig-leafed First Couple just before their banishment from Eden.

snippet: An easy stopover on the way to the French Riviera, Aix-en-Provence is the ideal destination for those who are looking for French culture and douceur de vivre. At the foot of the Montagne Sainte-Victoire so dear to Cezanne's palette, Aix boasts 300...
lead_paragraph: An easy stopover on the way to the French Riviera, Aix-en-Provence is the ideal destination for those who are looking for French culture and douceur de vivre. At the foot of the Montagne Sainte-Victoire so dear to Cezanne's palette, Aix boasts 300 sunny days per year, hotels particuliers of Italianate elegance, café terraces that can be used year-round, well-endowed museums and a world-renowned music festival in the summer. It is a young and cosmopolitan city, where you should walk rather than drive and tour the antique shops rather than surf the Web.

lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS
abstract: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Meeting God: Elements of Hindu Devotion'' explores Hinduism's rituals, prayers, customs and festivals in India through more than 75 photographs, devotional objects and videos. Accompanying the exhibition are color photographs by Steve McCurry depicting home and office shrines of Hindus, Sikhs and Jains from the New York metropolitan area. Through Feb. 24. Also in conjunction with the exhibition, ''Reflections of Our Spirit,'' with dance, music and theater, Sunday from 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. The main auditorium, where Imax films are shown, will be closed for renovations through the spring. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and 60+; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

snippet: Richard Kay Scholem reviews Giraffe Room in Inn at Great Neck, Long Island; photo; (A La Carte column) (M)
lead_paragraph: REFINED, often remarkably good food at reduced prices is the story at the three-month-old Giraffe Room in the Inn at Great Neck. There have been a number of restaurants in this little hotel at 30 Cutter Mill Road (516-773-2000) in the heart of Great Neck Village -- some excellent, others disappointing and all quite expensive. This casual but still classy room, with sculptured, stuffed and carved giraffes, diverse bright china and exceptional three-course, $19.95 fixed-price dinner from Sunday through Friday ($25.95 on Saturdays), is less stuffy and far more economical than its predecessors.

lead_paragraph: Carmine Galante, a murder suspect, may have been on the lam, but he was not about to lose track of what was going on in New York City crime circles. So every week Mr. Galante, a nephew of the former boss of the Bonanno crime family, ducked into a public library, found an idle computer and read GangLandNews.com, a weekly chronicle of the city's organized-crime scene.

lead_paragraph: THERE was a time when loud, dark and smoky was my kind of place. The drinks were cool, the food was hot, the men were single and the music was nothing but the blues.
abstract: THERE was a time when loud, dark and smoky was my kind of place. The drinks were cool, the food was hot, the men were single and the music was nothing but the blues.    These days, loud makes the children edgy; dark means I can't read the menu; and the only smoke I like is wood smoke on ribs or chicken.  But I will happily subject myself to that triumvirate of youth to eat at Makeda, a sophisticated Ethiopian restaurant that serves food so good  that I have added it to the very short list of places to take certain friends when they visit.

snippet: Parents, get ready for the slogan "only in theaters" once again. "Recess," the smart-alecky animated television series in which T. J. Detweiler and his schoolyard pals fight a never-ending battle against teacher-imposed doldrum...
lead_paragraph: Parents, get ready for the slogan ''only in theaters'' once again. ''Recess,'' the smart-alecky animated television series in which T. J. Detweiler and his schoolyard pals fight a never-ending battle against teacher-imposed doldrums at the Third Street School, comes to the big screen with ''Recess: School's Out,'' probably a momentary stopover on its trip to Blockbuster. Here, T. J., a prepubescent Hawkeye Pierce, is apprehended in one of his schemes by the authoritarian enemy, Principal Prickly, who bellows ''This time, I'm really gonna throw the book at you.'' But Prickly is checked in midtoss, since school is letting out for the summer.
abstract: Parents, get ready for the slogan "only in theaters" once again. "Recess," the smart-alecky animated television series in which T. J. Detweiler and his schoolyard pals fight a never-ending battle against teacher-imposed doldrums at the Third Street School, comes to the big screen with "Recess: School's Out," probably a momentary stopover on its trip to Blockbuster. The "Recess" movie springs from what could only be called the Post-It school of animation. (Is it possible for drawing to have only one dimension?) To make up for what could charitably be called a visual deficit, the movie comes up with a surfeit of notions. — Elvis Mitchell

snippet: A few tiny companies are making portable PC's that are cheap, simple, rugged, light, amazingly power-stingy word processors.
lead_paragraph: Max parks his hoverbike in front of his housing pod's acrylic dome; the artificial-intelligence sentry scans his retinas, then waves him inside. After switching on the hologram player, Max unloads his laptop, a $200 tablet that weighs one pound, contains no moving parts and can be dropped without damage. Its batteries are half depleted — only 350 hours of power left. He points the machine at his home computer and presses the Send button; the words he wrote on the road are silently beamed to the desktop machine, where they appear as though being typed by a secretary high on caffeine.
abstract: A few tiny companies are making portable PC's that are cheap, simple, rugged, light, amazingly power-stingy word processors.

snippet: Public Lives column profiles career of James J Cramer, founder of financial news Web site TheStreet.com; discusses decision to quit his $400 million private investment fund late last year; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IT would be a stretch to say that James J. Cramer is no longer a wild man since he quit his $400 million private investment fund late last year. He still looks fairly demented as he sits in his office at TheStreet.com, the financial news Web site -- he's a founder. His goateed face is turning beet red and scrunching into weird angles as tumbling stock prices flicker like Christmas lights on seven computer screens.

snippet: Jon Pareles profiles singer Macy Gray, who comments on her career and latest album, The Id; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: MACY GRAY can be a pretty good liar. On a recent Saturday night in New York City, giving an interview at an Upper East Side bistro, she was asked what she'd do afterward. ''I'm going to go home to the hotel,'' she deadpanned in her scratchy, sibilant voice. ''I'll drink my vitamin B-12 drink and my vitamin C and watch the science channel, and then I'm going to read the Bible. This is my 30th time reading the Bible. And I'm going to go to sleep and get up in the morning and exercise, and have an apple. That's pretty much the way I live.''

snippet: Silicon Alley pioneer Josh is not just online; he's on-edge
lead_paragraph: For almost six months, Harris, with the use of 32 well-placed Web cams and 70 hidden microphones, has been broadcasting his home life on the Web site www.weliveinpublic.com , which has streaming video, one-minute-old video stills, a chat room and a no-longer-updated schedule of events. Now Harris is selling the loft. Tanya Corrin, his former live-in girlfriend, has already departed and Harris, whose wealth in Jupiter stock options dwindled considerably two months before I met him, has also sold We Live in Public to Panopticon, a newly formed company owned by a former Pseudo employee. Harris, however, retains ownership of everything recorded in the loft, and he is still a 35% shareholder of Panopticon.

lead_paragraph: Judy Gibbons joined Microsoft Corp. six years ago to set up MSN, Microsoft's Internet network, in Britain. As European vice president of MSN, she now directs MSN operations in 15 European countries. In Europe, MSN is a network of Web sites, while in the United States, it is both a content provider and Internet access service. An engineering graduate, she has worked at Hewlett-Packard Co. and Apple Computer Inc. She spoke recently in Paris with Victoria Shannon of the International Herald Tribune.

byline.original: By Victoria Shannon, International Herald Tribune

lead_paragraph: EVERYTHING except the food at the Boulevard Inn in Kings Park seems to say pub, bar, gin mill. Red and green neon signs in its windows announce O'Doul's and Budweiser, Irish and American flags fly from an upper floor, and a shillelagh hangs over the bar of this roadhouse along Route 25 A that has held the likes of Popeye's, Sheehan's, Sue's Red Fox and Heide's. Diners must enter through a barroom blur of smoke, noise, Irish music and Union and team jackets.
abstract: EVERYTHING except the food at the Boulevard Inn in Kings Park seems to say pub, bar, gin mill. Red and green neon signs in its windows announce O'Doul's and Budweiser, Irish and American flags fly from an upper floor, and a shillelagh hangs over the bar of this roadhouse along Route 25 A that has held the likes of Popeye's, Sheehan's, Sue's Red Fox and Heide's. Diners must enter through a barroom blur of smoke, noise, Irish music and Union and team jackets.    Although the Boulevard Inn, at 605 East Main Street (631-979-8433), is the last place anyone would expect to encounter serious, sophisticated food, that's exactly what patrons find when they shut the barroom door behind them and enter the restaurant's tastefully appointed 36-seat, white-tablecloth dining room. Its roaring fire, soft music, antique breakfront, ship models, candles and flowers were in sharp contrast with the tavern's hubbub.

snippet: Roger Cohen reports on gastronomic relationship that developed between Marlene Dietrich and Markus Auer, young chef at German restaurant in Paris, around corner from Dietrich's Paris apartment during last years of Dietrich's life; Auer would bring...
lead_paragraph: The voice -- that voice -- the one of which Hemingway wrote that if she had nothing more, she could still ''break your heart with it,'' comes over the phone, a little more brittle than in the days when her legend grew. The young chef, recently arrived in Paris from his native Bavaria, is not sure what to make of the woman's peremptory question: Who are you? His response is mumbled. ''I am the Dietrich,'' she shoots back. ''Do you know who the Dietrich is?''

snippet: David Pogue State of the Art column on new portable devices, with word processor and calculator functions, that are an inexpensive, rugged and power-stingy alternative to palm-top computers; notes that they do not contain multimedia or Internet fe...
lead_paragraph: Max parks his hoverbike in front of his housing pod's acrylic dome; the artificial-intelligence sentry scans his retinas, then waves him inside. After switching on the hologram player, Max unloads his laptop, a $200 tablet that weighs one pound, contains no moving parts and can be dropped without damage. Its batteries are half depleted -- only 350 hours of power left. He points the machine at his home computer and presses the Send button; the words he wrote on the road are silently beamed to the desktop machine, where they appear as though being typed by a secretary high on caffeine.

snippet: Sephora's Face of Fashion Show, New York Fashion Week event, is first runway show devoted to makeup; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: FASHION is an unfriendly business, never more so than during the toxic-chic kiss-and-hiss days of Fashion Week. Beauty, however, is arguably the friendliest of style industries. Whereas fashion excludes, beauty includes. Fashion is affordable to a privileged few (although free to celebrities); beauty comes in all price brackets (and throws in free samples, to boot). Fashion seeks people who aspire to be so superior, they don't even allow themselves to eat; beauty welcomes all shapes and sizes. Fashion spits on the fat kid. Beauty cleans her off and gives her the name of a good lipstick.

snippet: James Traub article on Sen Joseph Lieberman focuses on how Lieberman is taking on Bush administration and positioning himself for 2004 presidential run; discusses whether Lieberman, in his own careful, temperate way, is really up for fight; photos...
lead_paragraph: Senator Joseph Lieberman has always been a Republican's idea of a model Democrat. When Al Gore selected Lieberman as his running mate last summer, George Bush's spokesman remarked that Gore ''has chosen a man whose positions are more similar to Governor Bush's positions than to his own.'' That was campaign hyperbole, but Lieberman had long occupied the conservative wing of his party on issues like defense spending, tax cuts, school vouchers and, notoriously, the entertainment industry. When Bush won and set about trying to define a new ideological center, Lieberman was one of the Democratic senators expected to join him there, at least on a number of key policy items.
abstract: James Traub article on Sen Joseph Lieberman focuses on how Lieberman is taking on Bush administration and positioning himself for 2004 presidential run; discusses whether Lieberman, in his own careful, temperate way, is really up for fight; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: My writing desk is a tankard-scoured tavern table that once saw service in an 18th-century inn. When I look up, the waved and bubbled window panes of my study offer a view that has changed very little in the 200 years since the glass was set in place. A small paddock rises gently to an apple orchard, the trees laced with white blossoms. An elderly stallion flicks at flies with a long, supple tail.
abstract: My writing desk is a tankard-scoured tavern table that once saw service in an 18th-century inn. When I look up, the waved and bubbled window panes of my study offer a view that has changed very little in the 200 years since the glass was set in place. A small paddock rises gently to an apple orchard, the trees laced with white blossoms. An elderly stallion flicks at flies with a long, supple tail.     At this time of year boughs of unfurling oak leaves hide the black slash of electric wires. And that's helpful; for every morning, after I turn off the urgent chatter of news radio -- its breathless headlines and daunting traffic reports -- I make my way up to this little room and attempt to leave my own time behind.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Cafe Melmar in East Hills, Long Island (A La Carte column) (M)
lead_paragraph: CAFE MELMAR'S finale is its finest hour. A cascade of desserts lights up tables throughout the subdued dining room at this new East Hills spot. Sid Grabill, the executive chef, who prepares them, learned his pastry making in Belgium and France and it shows. The sweets at this spiffy Italian-skewed spot don't take the predictable cannoli, ricotta cheesecake, tiramisù trail. There was ricotta on the dessert specials menu, but it is tucked into two warm, flaky, almost air-born apple strudel cylinders and escorted by a scoop of caramel gelato festooned with caramel syrup squiggles.

lead_paragraph: THERE are countless stories to tell: the man who walked into the Greenwich chapter of the American Red Cross and handed a worker a check for $10,000. ''I don't know what else to do,'' he said. The students in a South Windsor English honors class, who raised $5,000 and a truckload of food and supplies in 48 hours. The residents who filled up shopping carts at Wal-Mart and donated all their purchases to the Salvation Army.
abstract: THERE are countless stories to tell: the man who walked into the Greenwich chapter of the American Red Cross and handed a worker a check for $10,000. ''I don't know what else to do,'' he said. The students in a South Windsor English honors class, who  raised $5,000 and a truckload of food and supplies in 48 hours. The residents who filled up shopping carts at Wal-Mart and donated all their purchases to the Salvation Army.     In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, ''Everybody is just hungry to reach out and help,'' said Sandra Ahola, the principal of the Pomfret Community School in northeastern Connecticut. ''They want to show their compassion, their love, their caring.''

snippet: Herbert Muschamp article on Lillian Kiesler, widow of late Austrian architect Frederick Kiesler, who has died at age 91; focuses on her role of fostering husband's enduring influence on today's architecture; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: BEFORE his death in 1965, the Austrian émigré architect Frederick Kiesler made his wife, Lillian, promise that she would try to prevent people from calling him a Surrealist. When I finally met Lillian Kiesler toward the end of her life, I assured her that I would naturally record Kiesler's wishes but probably not honor them. Not all of his work was Surrealist, but the term does not, in my view, misrepresent the projects that hold the greatest interest for architects today. She was agreeable about it. Now I've kept my part of the bargain.
abstract: Herbert Muschamp article on Lillian Kiesler, widow of late Austrian architect Frederick Kiesler, who has died at age 91; focuses on her role of fostering husband's enduring influence on today's architecture; photos (L)

snippet: Bruce Weber reviews Shaw's Major Barbara, revived by Roundabout Theater; Daniel Sullivan directs production starring Cherry Jones, Dana Ivey and David Warner; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Judging by his résumé Daniel Sullivan doesn't have much interest in musicals. But as a theater director he seems to work with a baton and a tuning fork, as if a script were a score and the cast a chamber orchestra. He's interested in instrumentation. Mr. Sullivan has proven his nuanced ear in recent productions like David Auburn's ''Proof,'' Jon Robin Baitz's ''10 Unknowns'' and Donald Margulies's ''Dinner With Friends,'' ensemble works whose language creates fugues of harmony and discord rather than lyrical solos, and in Eugene O'Neill's ''Moon for the Misbegotten,'' with the howlingly painful aria of James Tyrone at its center. Mr. Sullivan's gift is for locating and sharpening the dramatic pitch of a playwright's work, as a respectful conductor would do for a composer.
abstract: Bruce Weber reviews Shaw's Major Barbara, revived by Roundabout Theater; Daniel Sullivan directs production starring Cherry Jones, Dana Ivey and David Warner; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: From the shoreline here, the flood walls of Rock Island, Ill., loom like a fortress across the rolling Mississippi River. Only the tops of buildings, safe from the floodwaters, can be glimpsed.
abstract: From the shoreline here, the flood walls of Rock Island, Ill., loom like a fortress across the rolling Mississippi River. Only the tops of buildings, safe from the floodwaters, can be glimpsed.    But not much comes between the river and Davenport's downtown businesses, historic district and parks. And that is the way people here like it. To preserve its connection with the river, the city decided against a costly flood prevention project in 1984 and to gamble on holding off occasional floods with frantic sandbagging.

snippet: "Ringing throughout the house was an alarm bell that no one but Alfred and Enid could hear directly. It was the alarm bell of anxiety."
lead_paragraph: The Madness of an autumn prairie cold front coming through. You could feel it: something terrible was going to happen. The sun low in the sky, a minor light, a cooling star. Gust after gust of disorder. Trees restless, temperatures falling, the whole northern religion of things coming to an end. No children in the yards here. Shadows lengthened on yellowing zoysia. Red oaks and pin oaks and swamp white oaks rained acorns on houses with no mortgage. Storm windows shuddered in the empty bedrooms. And the drone and hiccup of a clothes dryer, the nasal contention of a leaf blower, the ripening of local apples in a paper bag, the smell of the gasoline with which Alfred Lambert had cleaned the paintbrush from his morning painting of the wicker love seat.
abstract: "Ringing throughout the house was an alarm bell that no one but Alfred and Enid could hear directly. It was the alarm bell of anxiety."

lead_paragraph: BILL FLUHARTY is a spy. He watches people in their cars. Along with colleagues at Johnson Controls, where Mr. Fluharty is vice president for industrial design in North America, he films drivers and passengers on the open road, unawares, from a passing van.
abstract: BILL FLUHARTY is a spy. He watches people in their cars. Along with colleagues at Johnson Controls, where Mr. Fluharty is vice president for industrial design in North America, he films drivers and passengers on the open road, unawares, from a passing van.    This candid-camera crew visits rest areas, golf courses, malls and airports to look at autobound behavior patterns. ''At one airport, we nearly got arrested by security,'' Mr. Fluharty said. They have persuaded families to allow them to install a battery of in-car video cameras, each about the size of a deck of cards, for more extensive and detailed examination.

lead_paragraph: FINDING a good restaurant can be one of life's great hit-or-miss propositions, akin to throwing a dart at the Yellow Pages. lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:    My wife, Judy Corlin, was walking crosstown when she came alongside an older, somewhat disheveled woman who said simply, ''I'm hungry.'' She started reaching into her bag for some change when the woman shook her head and said she didn't want the money. She asked if my wife would get her an order of chicken soup in the Chinese restaurant she was standing in front of. The manager, she said, had warned her not to solicit inside.

lead_paragraph: Best Bet
abstract: Best Bet      At the Gilbert and Sullivan Light Opera Company of Long Island 20 core people connected with the company do double -- and in some cases triple -- duty. ''We love the shows so much and want them to be produced well while at the same time we need to keep expenses down,'' said Patricia Gallagher of West Hempstead.    So on Saturday when the company performs ''Ruddigore,'' Ms. Gallagher, a soprano with a degree in voice from the Peabody Conservatory of Music who in ''real life'' is an education evaluator for the New York City schools, will play Rose Maybud -- and handle the chores of costume mistress and, in her spare time, act as booking and business manager. Similarly, Phil Gellis directs and plays Sir Roderic and Martin Fuller built the set and appears as Sir Despard.

snippet: Shoba Narayan describes foods of her childhood as young girl in India when her family made long rail journeys with sumptuous meals packed beforehand; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE most important thing when traveling by train in India is not whether you have a seat in first class (more comfortable) or second class (more congenial), not whether you have confirmed tickets or even your destination. The most important thing is the size of your neighbor's tiffin carrier, the Indian lunchbox. If you are lucky, you will be seated near a generous Marwari matron whose way of making your acquaintance is to hand you a hot roti stuffed with potato saag.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Luna Caprese restaurant in Great Neck, Long Island (A La Carte column) (M)
lead_paragraph: GREAT NECK'S curse of the corner might be lifting. For years a succession of mostly Italian and often mediocre restaurants have resided, albeit briefly, at the intersection of Middle Neck and Cedar Roads. No sooner did one bite the dust than another took its place. But the newest in the line, Luna Caprese, shows promise of breaking the spell. It's not a perfect restaurant, but its virtues are impressive and its faults are minor.

snippet: Article by Ron Jenkins, theater professor, recalls Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Clown College, which he attended when it was in Venice, Florida, in 1970's; describes recent reunion of alumni; photo; school has closed because of Ringling b...
lead_paragraph: CLOWNS are walking catalogs of human imperfection, and comedy is the chronicle of their struggle to survive. With oversize shoes and trousers to match their Rabelaisian appetites, these slapstick warriors battle relentlessly against cream pies and pomposity. Their pants fall down to reveal knock-knees and ridiculous underwear. Their bodies flop face first into dung-scented sawdust. But despite the humiliations, clowning is an art in which the well-timed collapse of dignity is rewarded by the audience's laughter, a soothing and addictive sound that provides incentive to persevere in a war that pits red noses against etiquette and common sense.

snippet: Karal Ann Marling article on important role popular art, in form of Norman Rockwell posters, Matthew Brady photos, lapel pins, red, white and blue ribbon loops and makeshift shrines made up of store-bought greeting cards, candles and photos, plays...
lead_paragraph: ON a recent morning, because I had once written a book on images of the battle of Iwo Jima, I got a desperate call from a Swedish journalist. It seemed that some wire service photos of firemen at the World Trade Center closely resembled Joe Rosenthal's Pulitzer Prize-winning shot of five American marines and a combat medic raising the flag atop Mount Suribachi in 1945. What the reporter wanted to know was whether the Rosenthal picture was a fake: a posed propaganda piece intended to stir up patriotic fervor at home. By implication, I suppose, that would have made the World Trade Center image of a flag going up amid the rubble another specimen of American braggadocio.
abstract: Karal Ann Marling article on important role popular art, in form of Norman Rockwell posters, Matthew Brady photos, lapel pins, red, white and blue ribbon loops and makeshift shrines made up of store-bought greeting cards, candles and photos, plays in healing national psyche in times of crisis; holds fine art, which always surfaces much later, will eventually find its time; photos (L)

lead_paragraph: First-time visitors might never guess that Stuttgart is an autoworkers' town. Swank shops, stately gardens and restored castles adorn the downtown. Germany's Motor City lies in the Neckar River valley, ensconced in vineyards that receive subsidies to protect the rim of surrounding hills from developers. Despite its small size — only 560,000 residents — this Motown has a subway, which is spotless, and bright yellow trams wind through the hills.
